item.title: Samaritans and University report reveals dangers of social media’s self-harm content
item.description: Social media sites are still not doing enough to tackle self-harm content being pushed to users on their sites, says Samaritans.

item.title: Swansea University business partnership wins Wales Technology Award
item.description: A Swansea University collaboration with Aspire2Be, iBroadcast has been named Academia and Business Partnership of the Year at the Wales Technology Awards 2022.

item.title: S4 named winner at Wales STEM Awards ceremony
item.description: Swansea University’s Science for Schools Scheme (S4) was named the winner of the STEM Educational Programme of the Year in the Public Sector category at this year’s Wales STEM Awards.

item.title: Report shows the impact of Covid on Welsh school leaders’ wellbeing
item.description: New research has revealed the impact the Covid-19 pandemic had on senior staff in Welsh schools.

item.title: Swansea University's Annual Zienkiewicz Lecture Returns with Public Lecture on Redesigning and Implementing a 21st Century Energy System
item.description: On Wednesday, 9 November, Swansea University's Faculty of Science and Engineering will host its sixth Zienkiewicz Lecture, with distinguished guest speaker Professor Sir Jim McDonald, BSc, MSc, PhD, DSc, CEng, one of Scotland's most accomplished engineers.

item.title: Swansea-Africa research on climate crisis highlighted ahead of COP 27 gathering in Egypt
item.description: As world leaders gather in Egypt for the next COP27 summit, organised by the United Nations, four Swansea experts who conduct research on various aspects of the climate crisis are to feature in a showcase of Welsh collaborations with African universities.

item.title: Swansea Professor awarded prestigious medal for his outstanding contribution to STEM
item.description: The Institution of Engineering and Technology (IET) has awarded an IET Achievement Medal to Professor Tom Crick MBE of Swansea University.

item.title: Circular economy conference sees public sector unite to share ideas
item.description: Innovative ways the public sector in South Wales is tackling the climate emergency have been highlighted at a conference organised by the circular economy experts.

item.title: What does an academic look like? New book featuring Swansea expert highlights diversity of research and researchers
item.description: A new book which shows school pupils the diversity of research and of researchers includes a chapter by a Swansea expert in chemistry and climate change education who has learned that she is autistic.

item.title: Experts highlight link between hand size difference and Covid-19 severity
item.description: The difference in finger length between a person’s left and right hand may provide vital information about how ill they could get if they contract Covid-19.

item.title: Covid-19: Independent study to look at experiences of bereavement and the UK’s handling of the pandemic
item.description: A Swansea University study is seeking participants to explore public experiences on bereavement during the COVID-19 pandemic and on their views of how the pandemic was handled and what support they felt did, or did not, receive.

item.title: New project to develop next-generation radiotherapy cancer treatments
item.description: Swansea University physicists are using their research undertaken at the CERN facility in a major project aimed at developing next-generation, low-cost radiotherapy for cancer treatments that will be particularly effective when treating children and tumours near sensitive tissues.

item.title: Cost of living crisis having significant impact on mental health, study shows
item.description: New research has found that the cost of living crisis is having significant impacts on people’s mental health and emotional wellbeing.

item.title: Swansea University excels in latest global subject rankings
item.description: Swansea University features among the world's top institutions in 10 out of 11 subject rankings in the 2023 Times Higher Education World University Rankings by Subject.

item.title: More than £20 million awarded for UK theoretical physics
item.description: The Particle Physics and Cosmology Theory group in Swansea University’s Physics Department is one of 25 UK institutions that have been awarded more than £20 million to expand and test theories of how the universe works.

item.title: Professor continues to champion academic integrity on international stage
item.description: Swansea University’s Professor Michael Draper has been playing a key role at international events to highlight ethics and academic integrity.

item.title: Engineering at Swansea University Recognised for Innovation of the Year
item.description: General Engineering at Swansea University has been named a winner at the Engineering Talent Awards for Innovation of the Year 2022.

item.title: Ukrainian students given official welcome to Swansea University
item.description: Students from Ukraine were given an official welcome to Swansea at a University reception, where they were able to meet each other and find out more about the support available to them during their studies.

item.title: University creating state-of-art simulation facilities to train future health professionals
item.description: Work is now under way on high-tech new teaching facilities set to put Swansea University at the forefront of healthcare education.

item.title: New diagnostic tool could deliver health test results in two minutes
item.description: New diagnostic tool could deliver health test results in two minutes using fingertip sample - researchers develop proof of concept.

item.title: Research in the Community: University academics share their findings at public talks
item.description: In the first in a series of special talks, audiences will be invited to share a century of farming stories and take part in a discussion of what entrepreneurship means to the Welsh.

item.title: Green chemistry transforms facemasks into Ethernet cables
item.description: Swansea University academics have pioneered a process which converts the carbon found in discarded facemasks to create high-quality single-walled carbon nanotubes (CNT) which were then used to make Ethernet cable with broadband quality.

item.title: A sustainable approach to food pest control - Swansea hosts major international expert conference
item.description: A major international conference at Swansea University has brought together experts in integrated pest management (IPM) to discuss new ways of cutting reliance on harmful chemical insecticides.

item.title: New post-Covid study reveals children want more space and time to play
item.description: Children would like more space and time to play with their friends in school and at home, according to a new study led by Population Data Science researchers at Swansea University.

item.title: Step out to support suicide prevention charity
item.description: A beach walk to raise money and awareness of suicide in young people returns to Swansea later this month.

item.title: Groundbreaking research finds pelagic seabirds fly into the eye of the storm when faced with extreme weather conditions
item.description: New research led by Swansea University has found some pelagic seabirds fly directly towards the eye of a storm, which researchers think may help them avoid being forced onto land masses, reducing the risk of injury or death.

item.title: Swansea University hosts prestigious International Entrepreneurship Educators Conference 2022
item.description: Swansea University recently hosted academics, researchers and enterprise educators from around the world at the first in-person International Entrepreneurship Educators Conference (IEEC) in three years.

item.title: Rugby players past and present urged to help research on head impacts and concussion
item.description: As concussion in rugby comes under the spotlight, a Swansea researcher is inviting rugby players past and present to help with her research into head impacts, by sharing their experiences anonymously through a survey.

item.title: Ospreys and Swansea University: a pathway for rugby talent in Wales
item.description: In their fourth year as rugby performance partners, Ospreys and Swansea University (Sport Swansea) have ramped up their commitment to the support and development of young players this season.

item.title: Swansea University announces biggest Swansea Science Festival lineup to date
item.description: This year’s Swansea Science Festival will feature a week-long programme of in-person events, including a talk from award-winning TV presenter and conservationist Chris Packham, when it returns this autumn.

item.title: Mining vital metals without harming the environment – rivers expert involved in Philippines project
item.description: Mining metals that are crucial for net zero technologies, but in a way that does not harm the environment, is the aim of a joint UK-Philippines project which involves a Swansea University expert who has just returned from a research visit to the country.

item.title: Swansea University sports stars celebrated in new book
item.description: A new book written by Stan Addicott, A Century of Sport (Y Lolfa) presents the story of the past 100 years of sporting activity at Swansea University, from its founding in 1920 to present times.

item.title: New wellbeing project creating a buzz at Swansea University
item.description: Swansea University has introduced beehives to its campuses as part of a project to enhance student and staff wellbeing.

item.title: Tissue bank visit by Swansea expert will help boost multiple sclerosis research in Wales
item.description: Welsh research on multiple sclerosis has been strengthened by a visit to the Welsh Tissue Bank by a Swansea expert, made possible by the scholarship she was awarded by the Worshipful Livery Company of Wales.

item.title: Two Swansea University programmes shortlisted in the Wales STEM Awards 2022
item.description: Swansea University’s Science for Schools Scheme (S4) and Technocamps are thrilled to be amongst the prestigious businesses and individuals shortlisted in the 2022 Wales STEM Awards.

item.title: University helps pupils to put biorefinery in the spotlight
item.description: A group of pupils have not only been learning about a new way of using waste carbon emissions, but they have also made their own film to spread the word about the exciting project.

item.title: English teacher wins Rhys Davies Short Story Competition 2022
item.description: Laura Morris, an English teacher from Caerphilly, has won the 2022 Rhys Davies Short Story Competition for her story ‘Cree’, described by guest judge Rachel Trezise as “bristling with an irresistible melancholia and brimming with a bold confidence.”

item.title: Experts share high-tech ideas for improving experiences of amputees
item.description: Swansea University experts say digital transformation could bridge the gap between knowledge, revolutionary technology, and patient psychology, to improve the experiences of amputees and clinicians.

item.title: Senedd launch for new film helping to tackle online grooming
item.description: A new animation and report, developed by Swansea University’s online safety DRAGON-S project, to assist with anti-grooming training is being launched at a virtual Senedd meeting today.

item.title: Research on cancer and on concussion in women’s rugby to benefit from Livery Company awards
item.description: Two Swansea University researchers in sport and exercise sciences have won travel scholarships from the Worshipful Livery Company of Wales, which will allow them to further their research.

item.title: Economy Minister impressed by the £130m City Deal project that will boost the Sports and Medical Technology sectors
item.description: Welsh Government Minister for the Economy Vaughan Gething has visited the £130 million Swansea Bay City Deal Campuses project at Swansea University to understand more about how this exciting development will boost innovation and business growth in the expanding Medical Technology and Sports Technology sectors.

item.title: Cleaner water linked with smaller cockles that die younger, research on Burry Inlet reveals
item.description: Better water quality in Wales’ most famous cockle area is linked with smaller cockles that have a higher mortality rate, a new survey of fifty years of data has revealed.

item.title: New study identifies link between parental health literacy with COVID-19 test results in children
item.description: A Swansea University-led study has highlighted the importance of parental health literacy and suggests those with higher understanding and access to medical information were more likely to take their child to be tested for COVID-19 and be identified as positive.

item.title: Children given books from Dolly Parton’s Imagination Library read more often and perform better in school - new research
item.description: Children receiving books from the Imagination Library, set up by icon Dolly Parton, read more frequently and perform better at reading and development assessments than their peers, new Swansea University research has revealed.

item.title: Lost islands cited in Welsh folklore and poetry are plausible, new study of coastal geography and a medieval map suggests
item.description: A Welsh tradition dating to the medieval period of a landscape lost to the sea is plausible, new evidence on the evolution of the coastline of west Wales has revealed.

item.title: Swansea academic named Fellow of the Academy of Social Sciences
item.description: The Academy of Social Sciences has conferred the award of Fellow on 40 outstanding social scientists – including Professor Tom Crick MBE of Swansea University.

item.title: Industry support needed for new high-tech sorting plant to cut waste and boost recycling
item.description: Recycling more material from products at the end of their life – from rails and girders to cars and washing machines – is the aim of a Swansea-led team who are planning to build a new high-tech sorting plant, and calling for industry support.

item.title: Report Card raises concerns over health and well-being of children and young people
item.description: A ‘Report Card’ on the overall levels of physical activity (PA) of children and young people has assigned Wales a grade F - and raises concerns that this could have long-term implications for their health and well-being

item.title: How family tragedy has driven student’s desire to improve healthcare in her community
item.description: The unnecessary death of a much-loved relative has driven Bethel Ohanugo’s passion for improving healthcare in her native Nigeria.

item.title: University reveals ongoing support for Ukraine as it marks the country’s National Day
item.description: As Ukraine marks its national day on 24 August, Swansea University and staff members continue with efforts to support the country and its people, in the wake of the invasion by Russian forces in February.

item.title: CEIC conference set to share ideas on sustainable future of Wales
item.description: Environmental champions from across South Wales and beyond will be able to share ideas and gain valuable inspiration for supporting the sustainable future of Wales at a special event next month.

item.title: New course provides direct route to a career looking after surgical patients
item.description: If you have ever considered working in an operating theatre, at the very heart of hospital health care, a new course could put you on the perfect career path.

item.title: New 3D model reveals megalodon weighed more than 61 tonnes and could eat whole killer whales
item.description: Thanks to a megalodon which was discovered in the 1860s, an international team of scientists, including some from Swansea University, have been able to create, what is to date, the most complete 3D reconstruction of a megalodon – the largest shark that ever lived.

item.title: Swansea University to train even more medical students
item.description: Swansea University has secured more places on its successful Graduate Entry Medicine programme as part of a government investment to increase the number of Welsh-trained doctors for Wales.

item.title: Swansea student wins award for her outstanding contribution to Welsh language
item.description: Alpha Evans from Swansea University was crowned the winner of the Coleg Cymraeg Cenedlaethol's Merêd Award at the Ceredigion National Eisteddfod in August.

item.title: Materials science and engineering top the UK rankings for student satisfaction
item.description: Materials science and engineering at Swansea has been voted top in the UK for student satisfaction in the National Student Survey (NSS). This latest success follows awards for the department’s pioneering work on renewable energy technology.

item.title: EU experts combining knowledge to reduce wildfire danger
item.description: With the climate crisis increasing the risk of wildfires in the UK and many other parts of northern Europe, scientists from across the world are sharing their expertise to help tackle the dangers.

item.title: Students encouraged to find their space for a bright future at Swansea
item.description: With A-level results expected next week, many students may be feeling some uncertainty over beginning a university course following the challenges of the past few years.

item.title: Experts warn rising temperatures and extremely dry conditions contribute to unprecedented UK wildfire danger
item.description: The UK is experiencing not only record temperatures, but also unprecedented conditions favouring extreme wildfire danger and behaviour, according to wildfire experts.

item.title: Professor’s Covid contribution recognised with new honour
item.description: A Swansea academic at the forefront of shaping our understanding of Covid-19 has received further recognition for his work in the field of data science.

item.title: Enterprising Swansea University graduates celebrated at prestigious Welsh business awards
item.description: Two Swansea University graduate-led businesses have received top honours at this year's Wales StartUp Awards.

item.title: Swansea University named one of country’s best green spaces
item.description: The spectacular and diverse grounds of Swansea University’s two campuses have once again been judged among the best green spaces in Wales.

item.title: Innovative video game supporting mental health skills and psychological flexibility
item.description: A Swansea University researcher has developed a unique way to help build psychological resilience in young people, utilising gamification of mental health interventions and embedded learning.

item.title: The value of seagrass to the planet’s future is far greater than appreciated
item.description: Experts at the forefront of efforts to restore the UK’s coastal seagrass meadows say the remarkable plant’s contribution to the most important to-do list in the history of humankind should be reassessed.

item.title: Wales’ economic prospects at their most uncertain for 20 years – strategic intervention and awareness of interdependence needed, says expert
item.description: Wales’ economic prospects are more uncertain than at any time since the Assembly was established – and what is needed is more intervention by the Welsh Government and more collaboration by politicians at all levels, a leading expert argues in a new survey of the Welsh economy since devolution.

item.title: How learning about wellbeing can benefit university students’ own wellbeing
item.description: Studying wellbeing science as part of their courses could be a key way of improving how today’s students cope with the barrage of stressors they face, according to research.

item.title: The Solar OASIS: Clean, green, reliable electricity for village as first Active Building in India opens
item.description: A village in rural India will now get clean, reliable electricity for the first time, thanks to a newly opened Active Building, similar to those pioneered in Swansea, which generates, stores and releases its own solar power.

item.title: Call for breastfeeding data collection to measure medicine impact
item.description: A new paper from Swansea University in collaboration with ConcePTION, an Innovative Medicines Initiative (IMI) has called for breastfeeding data to be routinely collected in healthcare databases so that the long-term impacts of medicines taken by women during pregnancy and when breastfeeding, can be better understood.

item.title: University expertise to help new “Living Building” residents in Swansea to grow their own food on roof
item.description: Swansea University Centre for Sustainable Aquatic Research (CSAR) is a key partner in a pioneering Biophilic Living initiative which will provide a radical new approach to living and working within the city.

item.title: New study reveals the public make it more difficult for women to breastfeed
item.description: Disapproval or even disgust from the general public is one of the reasons why some women are reluctant to breastfeed outside of the home, according to researchers.

item.title: Swansea University collaborates with world’s largest women’s university to boost energy sector
item.description: Swansea University has signed a memorandum of understanding (MoU) with the largest women's university in the world to deliver a joint programme that will empower young Saudi female scholars within the energy sector.

item.title: Winners of the inaugural Chancellor’s Award announced
item.description: Swansea University celebrated the achievements of the three winners of its inaugural Chancellor’s Award, during graduation ceremonies held in Swansea Arena.

item.title: Marine biology expert caps Swansea career with PhD on seal behaviour
item.description: A marine biology student who chose Swansea University for his Bachelor’s and Master’s degrees has now made it a hat-trick by graduating with a PhD in Biological Sciences.

item.title: Breaking the mould – Jessica’s stellar success shows ASC doesn’t hold her back
item.description: A woman who is amongst the first in her family to go to university, and who has Asperger's Syndrome and ADHD, has paid tribute to all who supported her, encouraging others to follow in her wake, as she graduated with a master’s degree – with distinction - in History at Swansea University.

item.title: Experts unite to mark £2m boost for Supercomputing Wales
item.description: Data experts, technology suppliers and policymakers have gathered to celebrate the power and future of supercomputing in Wales.

item.title: Swansea University at the Ceredigion National Eisteddfod 2022
item.description: Swansea University is sponsoring Y Babell Lên (The Literary Tent) at the Ceredigion National Eisteddfod from 30 July to 6 August 2022.

item.title: Paramedic Michelle became kidney donor while working and studying through pandemic
item.description: A Barry woman is celebrating her graduation today which marks the culmination of an academic, professional and personal journey where she qualified as a Paramedic while working for the NHS through the pandemic and became part of a kidney donation exchange that helped her grandniece recover from serious illness.

item.title: Carol Vorderman maths bursaries of £2000 are open to all students - including those applying through clearing
item.description: Nine Carol Vorderman Maths Access Bursaries - worth £2000 each - are on offer to all students applying to do Mathematics at Swansea University, including those who apply through clearing.

item.title: Student in recovery from eating disorder celebrates graduation
item.description: A woman who has struggled with poor mental health and an eating disorder, is today celebrating as she graduates from Swansea University with an undergraduate degree in Sport and Exercise Science.

item.title: How new bacterial species discovered in Asian soil could help battle against antibiotic resistance
item.description: Swansea University experts have helped identify several news species of bacteria growing in arid Asian soil which could play a key role in the fight against antibiotic resistance.

item.title: Teenager’s tragic death inspired her mum to degree success and a new career
item.description: A mature student who suffered a devastating family tragedy during her degree course has now successfully graduated and dedicated her success to her late daughter.

item.title: Primary schools in Wales encouraged to take part in sun safety study
item.description: A researcher motivated by her son’s sunburn on a school sports day is encouraging primary schools across Wales to help develop sun safety guidelines for the spring and summer terms.

item.title: Swansea lecturer recognised for making a significant difference to students’ university life
item.description: A Swansea University lecturer who has provided immeasurable support to his students has been recognised with a prestigious award by the Coleg Cymraeg Cenedlaethol.

item.title: Delegates share expertise at Artificial Intelligence conference
item.description: Doctoral researchers and academics linked to two Centres of Doctoral Training (CDT) in Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Data Science came together to share ideas at the 2022 Artificial Intelligence Conference.

item.title: How steel in our buildings can generate clean energy – new University and Tata Steel collaboration
item.description: Solar roofing panels which are greener, lighter, cheaper and flexible, and which can be printed on the steel used in buildings, are the focus of a new three-year research collaboration between Swansea experts and Tata Steel UK.

item.title: Study reveals factors affecting public attitude towards Covid and the new normal
item.description: Partygate, a lack of media coverage and the perception that the virus is now milder could all affect future compliance with Covid guidance.

item.title: Researchers to develop digital solutions for defects in large-scale concrete construction
item.description: A team of researchers at Swansea University have been awarded £322,000 to develop digital solutions to reduce concrete construction defects.

item.title: UK MS Register celebrates 10th anniversary with £2m funding boost
item.description: The UK Multiple Sclerosis (MS) Register is not only celebrating a decade of vital data collection and research, it has also secured another £2 million of funding.

item.title: Chemistry expert secures Humboldt Foundation funding to recruit scientists for nanomaterials research
item.description: An expert in nanomaterials who is based in Swansea and Germany has secured around £250,000 of funding from the Humboldt Foundation to recruit early-career scientists to join his research team.

item.title: Swansea University Wins Prestigious AGCAS Award for Excellence 2022
item.description: Swansea University Employability Academy (SEA) has won the Equality, Diversity and Inclusivity category at this year's Association of Graduate Careers Advisory Services (AGCAS) Awards for Excellence.

item.title: Record number of Swansea University students compete in Commonwealth Games
item.description: Seven current Swansea University students and three graduates are set to compete at this summer’s Commonwealth Games in Birmingham.

item.title: University launches new anti-grooming animation aimed at keeping children safe online
item.description: A new animation and report recommendations, developed by Swansea University’s online safety DRAGON-S project, will provide vital tools to assist with anti-grooming training.

item.title: Climate change will increase chances of wildfire globally – but humans can still help reduce the risk
item.description: New research published today highlights how the risk of wildfire is not only rising globally due to climate change, but already at a pace faster than climate models have predicted.

item.title: Dream role for Egypt Centre’s new head
item.description: A childhood visit to a museum not only triggered Ken Griffin’s lifelong passion for Egyptology, it has also led to him landing his perfect job.

item.title: Children younger within the school year are more likely to be treated for ADHD
item.description: Children younger within the school year are more likely to be treated for ADHD which suggests immaturity may influence diagnosis.

item.title: Swansea University ranked 15th best university in the UK in StudentCrowd Awards
item.description: Swansea University has been ranked as the 15th best university in the UK in the StudentCrowd University Awards 2022, and has claimed the 20th position in the Students’ Union category.

item.title: Carbon capture research helps industry tackle carbon emissions
item.description: A collaboration between researchers at the Energy Safety Research Institute (ESRI) at Swansea University and insulation producer ROCKWOOL Limited has seen the installation of a new carbon dioxide demonstration unit at the company’s manufacturing plant in Bridgend, South Wales.

item.title: Swansea to lead international research network on violent online political extremism
item.description: Swansea University is to take on the leading role in an international research network, established in 2014 with EU funding, that studies online extremism and terrorism and responses to them.

item.title: University’s Egypt Centre in running for top museum award
item.description: Swansea University’s Egypt Centre has been shortlisted for the Kids in Museums Family Friendly Museum Award, it was announced today.

item.title: How terrorists use social media, and how to counter the threat – Swansea hosts international expert conference
item.description: How terrorist groups use social media, and how this can be countered, is the focus of a major international conference in Swansea, which brings together researchers, practitioners and representatives from governments and major tech companies around the world.

item.title: A sustainable approach to food pest control - Swansea to host major international expert conference
item.description: Feeding a growing population while reducing the environmental impact is an urgent challenge, but a major international conference at Swansea University will help by bringing together experts in integrated pest management. They will discuss new approaches to managing insect pests which will cut reliance on harmful chemical insecticides.

item.title: Safety boost as Singleton Park gets extra lighting
item.description: Singleton Park is set to get a new stretch of lighting to help keep students and staff safe.

item.title: Swansea University Academics Recognised as Top Women in Engineering
item.description: Swansea University's Professor Serena Margadonna has been named one of the UK's Top 50 Women in Engineering (WE50) by the Women's Engineering Society (WES).

item.title: Swansea University launches new Welsh language and culture strategy
item.description: Swansea University has launched a new five-year strategy outlining its ambitions and aspirations to continue its work of ensuring a prominent place for the Welsh language within the institution and the local community.

item.title: S4 report on the findings of the first 10 years of their science outreach programme
item.description: An analysis carried out by Swansea University Science for School Scheme (S4), a widening access STEM outreach programme established in 2012, has found that it is having a positive impact on young people from poorer areas by improving their career aspirations, and opinions on studying science at university.

item.title: University’s £2m boost to help turn bright ideas into global opportunities
item.description: Swansea University has won more than £2 million of funding to continue the drive forward the impact of its wide-ranging research and innovation.

item.title: Shortlist announced for the 2022 Rhys Davies Short Story Competition
item.description: A trainee schoolteacher, a Costa Short Story Prize finalist, and an author whose work has been broadcast on BBC Radio 4, are among the 12 authors shortlisted for the 2022 Rhys Davies Short Story Competition.

item.title: Swansea University sponsors Swansea City’s away shirt for 2022-23
item.description: Swansea University will be Swansea City’s front of away shirt partner and will sponsor the club’s travel and training wear for the forthcoming 2022-23 season.

item.title: UKRI Award for Technocamps
item.description: Technocamps has been awarded a UK Research and Innovation (UKRI) STEM Inspiration Award for Outstanding Contribution to Widening Participation, Diversity and Inclusion in STEM.

item.title: Vision for Swansea as centre for natural products is a step closer
item.description: The Swansea region could become a centre for natural products – from biopesticides to natural alternatives in cosmetics and pharmaceuticals – as funding has just been confirmed for a feasibility study into setting up a new hub to support research and businesses in this fast-growing sector.

item.title: Swansea University celebrates the life and work of Ludwig Wittgenstein with series of events
item.description: The life and work of Ludwig Wittgenstein, the Austrian-British philosopher regarded by many as the greatest philosopher of the 20th century, is to be celebrated with a series of events hosted by Swansea University in partnership with the Austrian Cultural Forum London and the Wittgenstein Initiative in June 2022.

item.title: Updated book examines today’s key tourism issues
item.description: The issues now facing visitor attractions around the world are explored in the latest edition of a book edited by a Swansea University tourism expert.

item.title: New Charter to promote sustainable travel in Swansea Bay
item.description: Swansea University hosted the launch of the Swansea Bay Healthy Travel Charter, signed by 11 leading organisations from across the region.

item.title: Swansea University announces GwyddonLe programme at the Denbighshire Urdd Eisteddfod 2022
item.description: Swansea University is pleased to sponsor one of the main attractions at the Urdd National Eisteddfod, the GwyddonLe pavilion, again this year – offering a full week of entertaining educational activities for children and young people.

item.title: Times Higher Education Impact Rankings 2022
item.description: Swansea University has ranked within the top 200 in the Times Higher Education Impact Rankings 2022.

item.title: Documentary project unites University and community to put spotlight on Gower
item.description: A unique film project which brought together Swansea University students, staff and the community to showcase the beauty of Gower will be officially launched next month.

item.title: Research and Innovation Awards mark Swansea University’s first major celebration since 2020
item.description: The breadth of Swansea University’s world-leading research was put in the spotlight at the Research and Innovation Awards 2022, with fourteen projects named as winners.

item.title: New study searching for Welsh speakers living in care
item.description: A Swansea University researcher is on the hunt for help to carry out a unique study into older Welsh speakers’ experience of care.

item.title: Research conference set to boost Swansea’s partnership with Grenoble and its European links
item.description: Swansea’s European links and research across the breadth of the institution will be strengthened when researchers working in Swansea and France meet in July, as part of a flourishing partnership with Université Grenoble Alpes (UGA).

item.title: Swansea University Employability Academy Shortlisted in Prestigious Careers and Employability Awards
item.description: Swansea University Employability Academy (SEA) has been nominated for five awards at the Association of Graduate Careers Advisory Services (AGCAS) Awards for Excellence 2022.

item.title: Sun safety for children – new research will explore the role of primary schools in preventing skin cancer
item.description: With skin cancer rates rising, much of it preventable, a new research project is to explore the role of primary schools in Wales and assess the effectiveness of sun safety policies in protecting children. The results will help improve prevention of skin cancer in Wales and beyond.

item.title: Health checks make life-saving difference for people with a learning disability
item.description: Welsh researchers have found that health checks help improve survival for people with a learning disability, especially those with autism or Down’s syndrome.

item.title: Funding to help semiconductor innovation achieve Net Zero ambitions
item.description: A new research and innovation facility based at Swansea University has received a funding boost of nearly £2.5m to host a project that will trial innovative emission reduction strategies for the semiconductor industry to help the sector deliver on Net Zero ambitions.

item.title: Patricia Lockwood wins 2022 Swansea University Dylan Thomas Prize with debut novel
item.description: American poet, novelist and essayist Patricia Lockwood has been awarded one of the world’s largest literary prizes for young writers – the Swansea University Dylan Thomas Prize – for her debut novel, No One Is Talking About This (Bloomsbury Publishing).

item.title: REF2021: Swansea University increases proportion of world-leading and internationally excellent research
item.description: The publication of the Research Excellence Framework 2021 (REF2021) results today (12 May) shows that Swansea University has improved the proportion of its world-leading and internationally excellent research. In the 2021 assessment, 86% of the University’s overall research was rated as 4*, (world-leading) or 3* (internationally excellent) - up from 80% in the previous REF exercise in 2014.

item.title: Detecting viruses in a pinprick
item.description: Scientists at Swansea University, Biovici Ltd and the National Physical Laboratory have developed a method to detect viruses in very small volumes.

item.title: Public health professor becomes Fellow of Academy of Medical Sciences
item.description: A Swansea University public health expert has been honoured by the prestigious Academy of Medical Sciences.

item.title: Seeing more species at the coast improves wellbeing – new research underlines benefits of biodiversity
item.description: Seeing a larger number of species on urban coastlines - from marine animals to seaweed - is likely to improve the wellbeing of local people and visitors, new research from a team at Swansea University has revealed. The findings provide further evidence that biodiversity brings wide-ranging benefits.

item.title: Education and earning potential hold the key to online dating popularity
item.description: Money can’t buy you love but it does make your profile more attractive when it comes to online dating. New research has revealed that level of education and income are particularly important, especially for men.

item.title: Swansea University at Hay Festival
item.description: Queer short stories from Wales, the everyday voices of the Covid-19 pandemic, and the winning title of this year’s Swansea University Dylan Thomas Prize are among the subjects set to delight audiences at the 35th Hay Festival between 26 May - 5 June.

item.title: New study suggests four in 10 in need of social care in Wales did not access services during the pandemic
item.description: As many as four in 10 people in Wales who may have needed social care did not access its services during the Covid-19 pandemic, according to a new report.

item.title: Special International Day of the Midwife award for Welsh midwives
item.description: Four midwives had special reason to celebrate this year’s International Day of the Midwife – it saw them being the first ever winners of a prestigious new honour.

item.title: New research shows how surfing may boost wellbeing of brain injury survivors
item.description: Generations of surfers know there’s nothing like catching the perfect wave, but now new research has looked at just how beneficial the power of the sea can be.

item.title: Swansea University academics honoured by Learned Society of Wales
item.description: Eight Swansea University academics are among the new entrants to the Learned Society of Wales’ Fellowship.

item.title: Swansea University Student Wins Two Awards at Parliamentary Science Competition
item.description: A chemistry PhD researcher has won two prizes at STEM for BRITAIN, a major scientific poster competition held at Parliament, which aims to give politicians “an insight into the outstanding research work being undertaken in UK universities by early-career researchers.”

item.title: Pan-Wales institute works to promote the health and wellbeing of the nation
item.description: The unique challenges facing health and wellbeing as we emerge from the pandemic into a new era have been highlighted in a new annual report launched today.

item.title: Partners ready to deliver research and innovation opportunities
item.description: Hywel Dda University Health Board and Swansea University will work together to help improve the health and well-being of communities in the three counties under a new agreement.

item.title: Swansea researchers develop new method to stop a molecule from rotating using ultra-low energy
item.description: Swansea researchers have developed a new method to stop a molecule from rotating using ultra-low energy, shedding new light on molecule-surface interactions.

item.title: Ancient oak trees to shed light on the climate of the past 4500 years
item.description: Researchers will soon be able to reconstruct the climate of north-west Europe including the UK over the last 4500 years, and to date wooden buildings and objects more accurately, by analysing the chemistry of ancient oak trees, through a new Swansea-led project just selected for €3 million in European funding.

item.title: Researcher wins international funding to help pioneer diabetes care
item.description: A Swansea University researcher’s pioneering work in the field of diabetes has helped earn her a major funding boost.

item.title: Insufficient menstrual cycle education provided in UK schools, study finds
item.description: Menstrual cycle education in UK schools is inconsistent and inadequate, and teachers feel they lack time, confidence, and subject knowledge, according to new research led by Swansea University.

item.title: Swansea University shortlisted for Whatuni Student Choice Awards 2022
item.description: Swansea University has been shortlisted in the Outreach and Widening Participation Submission Award category of this year’s Whatuni Student Choice Awards.

item.title: Castell Howell and Swansea Arena to sponsor Swansea University for Welsh Varsity
item.description: Welsh food wholesaler Castell Howell and the new Swansea Arena will be the principal sponsors for Swansea University at this year’s Welsh Varsity returns.

item.title: Swansea’s student entrepreneurs boost their business ideas with Big Pitch
item.description: Entrepreneurial students received a major boost for their business ideas at Swansea University’s annual Big Pitch Competition, sponsored by Santander Universities.

item.title: New review finds Autistic mothers face extra barriers to breastfeed
item.description: A new review by Swansea University, working with the University of Kent and non-profit organisation, Autistic UK, has found that breastfeeding support from midwives and health visitors is often not well suited to meet the needs of Autistic women.

item.title: Swansea University partnerships support research to protect and restore rainforests.
item.description: Leading researchers within the Faculty of Science and Engineering are continuing a successful partnership with a leading rainforest research programme in Borneo following a new £330,000 research grant.

item.title: Swansea University and Aspire2Be collaboration recognised at prestigious awards
item.description: Swansea University and Aspire2Be have been recognised as highly commended at the National Undergraduate Employability Awards for their collaborative project, iBroadcast.

item.title: QS World University Ranking by Subject 2022: Swansea University achieves its best ranking
item.description: Swansea University has delivered its best-ever performance in a leading global university ranking by subject released today.

item.title: New Research Project Takes Steps Towards a Circular Economy
item.description: A research project aimed at bringing a truly circular economy one step closer, has received a £1.2 million research grant from the Engineering and Physical Science Research Council (EPSRC).

item.title: Swansea student wins £1,000 in Dealer Tech Competition
item.description: A Swansea University student has won £1,000 in a competition for his idea to create an online database for suppliers, manufacturers and dealerships in the automotive industry.

item.title: Swansea academic awarded best thesis prize
item.description: A Swansea University academic has won the Agronomy Best PhD Thesis Awards for his research to establish a new combination of methods for the earlier detection of plant disease in food crops, which could have global economic and environmental impact.

item.title: University joins in special celebration of Swansea’s support for migrants
item.description: Swansea University is playing a key role in helping shape youngsters’ knowledge about migration at a unique new city exhibition.

item.title: Under-represented voices dominate the 2022 Swansea University Dylan Thomas Prize shortlist
item.description: The shortlist for one of the world’s largest literary prizes for young writers – the Swansea University Dylan Thomas Prize – has been announced. From Sri Lanka to Trinidad, Texas, and Ireland via the Middle East, this year’s shortlist features a powerful, international collection of writers who are offering platforms for under-represented voices.

item.title: Improving asphalt road pavement using engineered nano mineral composites
item.description: A novel and eco-friendly nano asphalt binder has been developed by researchers at Swansea University and the Technical University of Braunschweig.

item.title: How fingers could point to a link between low testosterone and Covid hospitalizations
item.description: Could the length of a person’s fingers provide a clue to how ill they might get after contracting Covid-19?

item.title: Swansea University signs Technician Commitment
item.description: Swansea University has signed the Technician Commitment, joining more than half of UK universities and several research institutions in backing a pledge to support their technicians.

item.title: Protecting the Amazon’s giant trees - Swansea geographer's visit gathers key data and secures government commitment
item.description: A Swansea geographer has recently returned from the Amazon with vital data on giant trees of over 80 metres, which she first helped discover in 2018. As a result of this work, the State government in Brazil has pledged to enact a Bill to protect them and their surroundings.

item.title: University shines a light on why recycling is so vital
item.description: Swansea University showed its commitment to sustainability by going green to mark Global Recycling Day.

item.title: Students’ transatlantic trip to share AI research
item.description: PhD students from Swansea University have been sharing their cutting-edge research into artificial intelligence with colleagues in America.

item.title: Multiple sclerosis and marine life research to benefit from Livery Company awards
item.description: Two Swansea University researchers have won travel scholarships from the Worshipful Livery Company of Wales, which will allow them to further their research and share it with fellow experts.

item.title: Vice-Chancellor's statement on Ukraine
item.description: At Swansea University, we join with universities and academic organisations around the world in condemning unequivocally the Russian state’s decision to invade Ukraine.

item.title: Royal visit to life-changing research facility in Swansea
item.description: HRH The Countess of Wessex, patron to The Scar Free Foundation, visited the world-leading facial reconstruction research programme based at Swansea University, meeting patients who could benefit from these ground-breaking studies.

item.title: Visit to cultural attaches boosts Swansea’s links with Oman and Qatar
item.description: Stronger links with Oman and Qatar were the subject of discussions during a visit by a senior Swansea University delegation to the Cultural Attaches’ offices for both countries in London.

item.title: Greener industries - chemical engineers find new ways of reusing carbon to tackle the climate crisis
item.description: Swansea University chemical engineers are finding new ways to capture and reuse carbon by turning it into useful products to help tackle the climate crisis.

item.title: New study explores how pollutants indoors impact child health
item.description: Scientists at Swansea University have launched a major study to discover how everyday pollutants impact the development and health of fetuses and children.

item.title: Covid-19 pandemic increased UK network news coverage of devolved issues, study finds
item.description: A new Ofcom-commissioned study has revealed UK network news providers have enhanced their coverage of devolved topics, largely due to the pandemic.

item.title: International Women’s Day with Baroness Tanni Grey-Thompson
item.description: Baroness Tanni Grey-Thompson will be speaking about the challenges she has faced and how she has overcome them, following the International Women’s Day 2022’s theme #BreakTheBias.

item.title: Storing summer heat to use in winter – new research on thermal energy storage could cut bills and boost renewables
item.description: New technology that could store heat for days or even months, helping the shift towards net zero, is the focus of a new project involving the Active Building Centre Research Programme, led by Swansea University, which has just been awarded funding of £146,000.

item.title: Swansea University scientist to present his research in Parliament
item.description: Thomas Spriggs, a PhD research student at Swansea University, is to present his physics research in Parliament, to a panel of expert judges and politicians, as one of the finalists in STEM for Britain 2022.

item.title: Swansea University ranked 26th in the Stonewall Workplace Equality Index
item.description: Swansea University has been named in the UK’s top 100 most inclusive employers for LGBTQ+ staff, for the sixth time in a row.

item.title: Free sessions offer chance to find out more about part-time degree
item.description: If you are looking to return to education or just want to see what it is like to study, Swansea University is offering a series of free sessions to give you first-hand experience.

item.title: Swansea University awarded Queen’s anniversary prize for revolutionary renewable energy technology
item.description: Swansea University has been awarded a Queen’s Anniversary Prize in recognition of its Materials Science and Engineering research that is leading a revolution in renewable energy technologies, particularly solar electricity and heat generation and storage.

item.title: New app helping young people speak out to shape their local community
item.description: A new app has just been launched that puts the power to rate and help improve communities in the hands of young people.

item.title: Swansea University’s Smart Garments used by elite athletes
item.description: UK Government Minister David TC Davies has visited the £132 million Swansea Bay City Deal Campuses project to see how the technology for Smart Garments has been developed and was used by athletes, including medal winners, in last year’s Tokyo Olympics.

item.title: Swansea University helps embed Swansea’s rich industrial heritage into the curriculum
item.description: Swansea University has launched a new digital resource pack for 9-11-year-olds which will help pupils learn about Swansea’s globally significant copper industry while developing their literacy, numeracy and digital competency skills.

item.title: Study reveals lockdown impact on youngsters’ mental health
item.description: Young people were the hardest hit as the second Covid-19 lockdown took its toll on the mental health and wellbeing of the Welsh population, new research has revealed.

item.title: Covid-19: Study seeks participants to explore public attitudes to social care in Wales
item.description: A Swansea University study is seeking participants to explore public attitudes to social care in Wales following the Covid-19 pandemic.

item.title: UK is ‘international outlier’ in its approach to Covid in children, argue experts
item.description: The UK is an ‘international outlier’ in its approach to protecting children from Covid, argue experts in The BMJ today.

item.title: University helping to improve medicine safety in early motherhood
item.description: Researchers from Swansea University and SAIL Databank are playing a key role in a multi-million pound international project to improve the safety of medicines given to mums-to-be and breastfeeding mothers.

item.title: Swansea University Professor Named Expertscape Expert in Sedentary Behaviour
item.description: Professor Kelly Mackintosh from Swansea University's School of Sport and Exercise Sciences has been recognised as a world-leading expert in sedentary behaviour.

item.title: Diverse and global voices dominate the longlist for the Swansea University Dylan Thomas Prize
item.description: The international longlist for one of the world’s largest literary prizes for young writers – the Swansea University Dylan Thomas Prize – has been announced. From Sri Lanka to Trinidad, Texas, and Ireland via the Middle East, this year’s longlist features a powerful, international collection of writers who are offering platforms for under-represented voices.

item.title: Swansea University leads on first-of-its-kind research exploring gambling and wellbeing in the Royal Air Force
item.description: A new study by Swansea University and the RAF Benevolent Fund has been published, exploring wellbeing issues among serving RAF personnel, with a key focus on problem gambling, alcohol use and mental health.

item.title: Swansea University appoints Registrar and Chief Operating Officer
item.description: Swansea University has announced the appointment of Niamh Lamond as Registrar and Chief Operating Officer, following a competitive external recruitment process. Niamh has been covering the role in an interim capacity since July 2021 and will now continue in post on a permanent basis.

item.title: £17m funding for collaborative data research in Wales
item.description: An initiative involving Swansea University that has transformed how data can be used to provide insight into social and economic issues in Wales will continue, thanks to an investment of almost £17 million.

item.title: University praised for pioneering work championing the importance of a circular economy
item.description: Swansea University’s commitment to promoting a circular economy has led to it winning international recognition.

item.title: Scientists use GPS to track baboon troop's movement in urban spaces for the first time
item.description: In a unique study, researchers from Swansea University (UK) and the University of Cape Town in South Africa have used GPS collars to study the collective behaviour of a troop of baboons living on the outskirts of the City of Cape Town.

item.title: Welsh Varsity returns after two-year hiatus
item.description: Following a two-year break due to the Covid-19 pandemic, the date for the 2022 Welsh Varsity between Cardiff and Swansea Universities has been confirmed.

item.title: Gaining public support for COVID-19 policies: politicians polarise, but experts are trusted
item.description: Policies to tackle COVID-19 are more likely to get broad public support if they are proposed by experts or bipartisan coalitions, rather than by politicians from only one party, a new study of seven countries involving a Swansea University academic has shown.

item.title: Experts emphasise the role of wellbeing in human health
item.description: The importance of wellbeing and its role in health has been highlighted in a new paper by Swansea University academics.

item.title: Babies to benefit from first milk bank hub in Wales
item.description: Swansea University and Swansea Bay University Health Board have launched a new partnership with the Human Milk Foundation (HMF) that will see a donor milk bank hub in Wales for the first time.

item.title: Swansea University academics support NASA mission with mapping of dams across rivers
item.description: A new spatial database of dams and other river obstructions built partially or fully across the world's largest rivers has been published.

item.title: Study into link between mental health and substance abuse issues on young people’s mortality
item.description: Young people with a history of mental health and drink and drug issues are more likely to die than those with a mental illness or who use substances alone.

item.title: Professor in Public Health recognised in New Year’s Honours
item.description: A public health expert recognised by the Queen says his honour is a reflection of just how highly the work of Swansea University’s SAIL Databank is regarded.

item.title: Experts say pupils’ wellbeing affected by online learning during lockdown
item.description: Secondary school children struggled to concentrate and engage with schoolwork in the move to online learning during lockdown, negatively affecting their confidence and wellbeing, according to a new study.

item.title: The impact of deepfakes on trust in user-generated evidence - €1.5 million grant for Swansea expert
item.description: A Swansea law expert has been awarded €1.5 million to examine how public perceptions of deepfakes – AI-manipulated images, videos or audio – affect trust in user-generated evidence of human rights violations.

item.title: Professor Tavi Murray awarded CBE in New Year’s Honour List
item.description: Professor Tavi Murray, Professor of Glaciology in the Faculty of Science and Engineering at Swansea University has been awarded a CBE in the New Year’s Honours list for services to Glaciology and Climate Change Research.

item.title: Smart charging can save electric vehicle drivers £110 a year - and cut carbon footprint by 20%
item.description: Drivers of electric vehicles could save an average of £110 a year - and cut their carbon footprint by 20% - by using “smart charging” to power up their cars at the best possible times, a report by a research team involving Swansea University experts has shown.

item.title: Using the Earth’s noise to see beneath the Greenland ice sheet – new research gives most detailed picture yet
item.description: The noise created by the Earth’s movements has been used to build up a detailed picture of the geological conditions beneath the Greenland Ice Sheet and the impact on ice flow, in new research led by Swansea University.

item.title: Joint bid secures PhD funding to research Welsh and the New Curriculum in the Early Years.
item.description: Swansea University has successfully secured funding for a PhD to research a topic relating to the Early Years and the New Curriculum following a joint bid with Cardiff Metropolitan University and Mudiad Meithrin, a charity specialising in childcare and early years in Wales.

item.title: Swansea University awarded £2.4 million renewal funding for world-class dementia data repository
item.description: Swansea University has been awarded £2.4 million in funding to continue and develop the Dementias Platform UK (DPUK) Data Portal - a world-class data repository for dementia research.

item.title: 2022 Rhys Davies short story competition open for entries
item.description: The distinguished national Rhys Davies Short Story Competition for writers from, or living in, Wales is now open for entries.

item.title: Single mother who fought on COVID-19 frontline celebrates master's degree with daughters
item.description: A nurse of fourteen years has advanced her career with a master's degree at Swansea University, all while being a single mother to two young children and working on the frontline.

item.title: Swansea named as top 10 UK university for environmental performance
item.description: Swansea University is one of the top ten universities in the UK for environmental and ethical issues, the new league table compiled by People and Planet, published by The Guardian, has revealed.

item.title: Chevening Scholar overcomes COVID-19 setbacks to graduate with human rights degree
item.description: An international student has graduated with distinction from Swansea University, despite COVID-19 restrictions preventing him from travelling to the UK at the start of his degree.

item.title: Swansea’s Richard Burton Archives retains accreditation status
item.description: The Richard Burton Archives at Swansea University, which holds material of local, regional and national significance, has retained accreditation status in recognition of its high standards, both in looking after valuable records, and in making them available to researchers and the wider community.

item.title: Finding the right formula project focusses on feeding babies safely
item.description: A collaborative community science project developed between parents and researchers to assess the safety of powdered infant formula preparation techniques in the home has been launched by Swansea University and independent public health nutrition charity, First Steps Nutrition Trust.

item.title: Swansea University alumnus Professor Lyn Evans named Institute of Physics Honorary Fellow
item.description: Renowned Welsh physicist Professor Lyn Evans has been appointed an Institute of Physics 2021 Honorary Fellow.

item.title: Study introduces framework to understand new class of curved lattice materials
item.description: A new study from Swansea University has introduced a framework to calculate the material properties of a new class of two-dimensional curved hexagonal lattices that could be used in the production of improved mechanical metamaterials found in bio-engineering, stretchable electronics, impact absorption and soft robots.

item.title: Swansea University awarded Queen’s Anniversary Prize for revolutionary renewable energy technologies
item.description: Swansea University has been awarded a Queen’s Anniversary Prize in recognition of its Materials Science and Engineering research that is leading a revolution in renewable energy technologies, particularly solar electricity and heat generation and storage.

item.title: Swansea animal movement expert awarded prestigious medal for scientific contribution
item.description: Professor Emily Shepard, an expert in the movement ecology of wild animals, has been awarded the prestigious Zoological Society of London (ZSL) Scientific Medal, in recognition of her outstanding research.

item.title: £1.73m additional funding to expand project in semiconductor technology and applications
item.description: The Welsh Government has announced additional funding of £1.73 million for a project, which involves Swansea University and partners, developing world-leading semiconductor process technologies. Applications include autonomous vehicles, novel devices for clean energy, future mobility, artificial intelligence, advanced packaging, and biosensors and wearable sensors.

item.title: How school attendance data could play crucial role in targeting mental health support for pupils
item.description: Poor school attendance impacts a child’s future, not just through their educational achievement but also socially and developmentally.

item.title: Swansea University academics use pandemic to reach out to schools with innovative game
item.description: Academics and students from Swansea University have used experiences and knowledge of the Covid-19 pandemic to develop an interactive and innovative game.

item.title: Rainforests of the sea - new guide to help restore seagrass involves Swansea expert team
item.description: A team of conservation scientists, including 11 Swansea University researchers, have published a landmark guide to support efforts to restore seagrass beds, which capture carbon more quickly than rainforests do.

item.title: Parental depression is associated with worse childhood mental health and educational attainment - new study
item.description: Children who live with a parent who has depression are more likely to develop depression and to not achieve educational milestones, according to a new study published in the open-access journal PLOS ONE by Sinead Brophy of Swansea University and colleagues.

item.title: Swansea University's annual Zienkiewicz Lecture returns with online public lecture on the challenges of delivering net zero
item.description: On Wednesday, 24 November, Swansea University's Faculty of Science and Engineering will host its fifth Zienkiewicz Lecture, with special guest Baroness Brown of Cambridge DBE FREng FRS, Julia King.

item.title: Software to reduce emergency hospital admissions - Welsh GPs report mixed experiences on usability and benefit for patients
item.description: A software tool meant to help reduce emergency hospital admissions is of limited use and benefit to patients, a new study of GPs’ views and experiences has revealed.

item.title: The 100% recyclable meat tray – new packaging does away with throwaway absorbent pads
item.description: A Swansea researcher has invented a new type of plastic packaging for raw meat which avoids the need for non-recyclable pads inside the trays to soak up the juices, meaning the whole of the packaging tray can now be recycled.

item.title: Swansea University Media Students Cover Key Global Issues During Hillary Rodham Clinton Global Challenges Summit
item.description: Students from Swansea University’s Department of Media and Communications have been given the rare opportunity to experience the reality of a live newsroom.

item.title: Inaugural Global Drug Policy Index released
item.description: The inaugural edition of the Global Drug Policy Index (GDPI), released on 8 November 2021 by the International Drug Policy Consortium, ranks Norway, New Zealand, Portugal, the UK and Australia as the five leading countries on humane and health-driven drug policies.

item.title: Volunteer wins top award for her commitment to sharing the wonders of Egypt Centre
item.description: A long-standing volunteer has been honoured for her dedication to Swansea University’s award-winning Egypt Centre.

item.title: Swansea University chosen as one of four hubs for Being Human 2021, the UK’s only national festival of the humanities
item.description: Being Human Festival 2021 will return between 11-20 November with Swansea University featuring as one of four UK hubs for the seventh consecutive year.

item.title: Researcher welcomed back to share expertise at virtual summit
item.description: Swansea University research into therapeutic treatments for ovarian cancer will be highlighted to a global audience at a virtual online conference next week.

item.title: Professor receives prestigious award from Danish university
item.description: An international collaboration involving Swansea experts will boost pioneering research into how exercise can benefit stroke patients.

item.title: International meetings set to bring AI experts together to develop research
item.description: Artificial intelligence experts from Swansea University will be sharing their knowledge with international peers at a series of special events, kicking off this month.

item.title: Triple awards success for University diabetes expert
item.description: A Swansea University diabetes expert was named a three-time winner at a major UK healthcare awards.

item.title: City exhibition showcases how youngsters want to Be Seen
item.description: A unique exhibition featuring virtual reality artwork created by young people to express their feelings about their mental health is being held in Swansea this month.

item.title: University sharing expertise as part of transatlantic research project
item.description: Swansea University has joined landmark international project examining the history and politics of deindustrialisation.

item.title: Lack of clarity in government messaging could lead to low public compliance if restrictions are reintroduced, expert warns
item.description: As health leaders call on the UK Government to implement Covid-19 contingency plans, a leading Covid-19 behavioural expert from Swansea University has warned that clear messaging from the UK and devolved governments will be essential to ensure high public compliance if additional measures are introduced.

item.title: Leading the switch to net zero industry: new £20 million facility to help develop a green economy in Wales
item.description: South Wales is set to build on its strength and expertise in steel and metals innovation with the launch of a new £20 million facility to help industry in the region create a low-carbon future.

item.title: New study reveals UK military veterans with gambling problems have higher social and economic costs of around £600 per person
item.description: A new study has revealed UK Armed Forces veterans experiencing problem gambling cost society more in terms of their higher use of health and social care services, brushes with the police, loss of working hours, welfare benefits and heavier debt burden.

item.title: University welcomes back charity beach walk
item.description: A beach walk to raise money and awareness of suicide in young people returns to Swansea this weekend.

item.title: Study highlights possible protective impact of breast milk and amniotic fluid on coronavirus variant in pregnant women and newborns
item.description: New collaborative research from Swansea University and the University of Aberdeen has identified potential protective effects in breast milk and amniotic fluid against SARS-CoV-2.

item.title: Latest wellbeing survey offers chance to share your pandemic experiences
item.description: A pioneering study examining the impact of Covid-19 on the mental health and wellbeing of Welsh people is appealing for more information from the public.

item.title: Ecology expert helping to highlight devastating loss of biodiversity in UK
item.description: A Swansea University ecologist is part of the team behind an important new online tool which reveals just how the biodiversity of regions has changed over time.

item.title: Prize-winning pupils share their vision for the future of University
item.description: Swansea University’s commitment to encourage youngsters with a passion for learning has been highlighted once again at this year’s Swansea Science Festival.

item.title: Aerial scanning can help protect food crops against devastating disease
item.description: Virulent diseases which devastate food crops like coffee, almond, citrus and grapevines with serious global economic and environmental consequences, could be controlled by large-scale aerial scanning, says new collaborative research involving Swansea University.

item.title: Developing rugby players – new England framework draws on Swansea sport scientist’s expertise
item.description: A new framework for developing rugby players of all levels, launched by England’s Rugby Football Union (RFU), has drawn on the expertise of a Swansea sport scientist.

item.title: New report demands action to address mental health inequalities faced by Deaf community
item.description: Deaf people in Wales are experiencing significant mental health inequalities because there is a lack of accessible services, no specialist Deaf mental health service in Wales and limited training about Deaf issues for health and care workers, according to a new report.

item.title: Child health expert shortlisted for top research honour
item.description: A Swansea University academic is in the running for a nationwide award for her pioneering work in the field of child health and education during her PhD.

item.title: Professor becomes clean air champion for Wales
item.description: A Swansea University expert has been named as one of the UK’s latest clean air champions.

item.title: University gains double recognition for its outstanding green spaces
item.description: Swansea University has once again been named among the country’s best green spaces.

item.title: World Sight Day: Supporting sight impaired people in the post pandemic world
item.description: To mark World Sight Day (14 October), a new report by a Swansea University research team has revealed that blind and sight impaired people still face barriers that prevent them from fully utilising digital services.

item.title: Swansea University student nurses in running for top honours
item.description: The outstanding nurse training offered at Swansea University has once again been highlighted at this year’s Student Nursing Times Awards.

item.title: Craft brewery set to use microalgae to reduce CO2 emissions
item.description: Swansea University bioscientists have teamed up with a West Wales microbrewery to help it reduce its CO2 emissions.

item.title: Swansea University announces line up for the 2021 Swansea Science Festival
item.description: October will see the return of the Swansea Science Festival, hosted by Swansea University, in partnership with the National Waterfront Museum.

item.title: Six Swansea projects funded as part of £6.5 million for life-saving research in Wales
item.description: Six Swansea University researchers have been awarded funding by Health and Care Research Wales, to investigate topics ranging from sun safety policies in primary schools to the impact of COVID-19 on people with epilepsy.

item.title: Centre for Ageing and Dementia Research launches app to support digital inclusion of older persons
item.description: The Centre for Ageing and Dementia Research (CADR) have launched their first app, in support of the International Day of Older Persons.

item.title: Welsh science world-leading in addressing the biggest challenges facing the planet
item.description: Wales may be a small country, but it punches above its weight in the quality and the quantity of the research it carries out. A new report highlights the particular strength of Welsh science in contributing to efforts to meet the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs).

item.title: Current and former world leaders to open Hillary Rodham Clinton Global Challenges Summit
item.description: Swansea University has today (30th September) announced the speakers who will participate during the opening day of the inaugural Hillary Rodham Clinton Global Challenges Summit, which runs from 8th to 10th November.

item.title: Swansea technology helps power top British athletes to Tokyo success
item.description: British athletes in Tokyo, including top medal winners, used wearable technology designed by Swansea University experts, with a printed carbon ink heater to keep their muscles warm before competing.

item.title: New course to explore the world of Egyptian textiles
item.description:
Explore with Me: Textiles and Ancient Egypt

The 10-week course is available to anyone and will explore the different methods of textile design that were used in Ancient Egypt.

item.title: Medical School student’s success in prestigious writing challenge
item.description: An initiative aimed at promoting the knowledge available at your local pharmacy proved the perfect inspiration for a Swansea University student’s award-winning success.

item.title: Public torn over Covid-19 booster jabs and flu vaccinations
item.description: New research by a Swansea University expert has highlighted how torn members of the public are over the issue of Covid-19 booster vaccines and the flu vaccine.

item.title: Swansea University introduces free course for adult learners seeking a change in direction
item.description: As part of Adult Learners Week (20 - 26 September 2021), Swansea University will be holding a free course encouraging adults to develop new skills.

item.title: Inaugural Hywel Teifi Memorial Scholarship winner announced
item.description: Alpha Evans of Lampeter has won the inaugural £3,000 Hywel Teifi Memorial Scholarship.

item.title: Swansea University to host International Entrepreneurship Conference
item.description: Swansea University are delighted to announce that we will be hosting the International Entrepreneurship Educators Conference (IEEC) 2022.

item.title: Swansea retains its UK top 25 position in the Guardian University Guide 2022
item.description: Swansea University has retained its UK top 25 position in the prestigious Guardian University Guide, ranking 24th nationally and is once again top in Wales in the latest 2022 edition, published on Saturday 11 September.

item.title: Hillary Rodham Clinton to convene Global Challenges Summit with Swansea University
item.description: Swansea University will host the inaugural Hillary Rodham Clinton Global Challenges Summit in November.

item.title: Swansea-born writer wins Rhys Davies Short Story Competition
item.description: Naomi Paulus has won the 2021 Rhys Davies Short Story Competition for her story Take a Bite, a “delightful, wistful, satisfying piece” in which a young woman, Rhian, returns home to the voices and rituals of her mother and aunts for an important family event.

item.title: University secures extra places to train more medical students
item.description: Swansea University has been able to offer additional places on its graduate entry medicine programme as part of a government investment to increase the number of doctors being trained in Wales.

item.title: Swansea University graduate named as finalist in prestigious alumni awards
item.description: Swansea University alumnus Dr Daniel Bassey has been selected as a global finalist in the British Council Study UK Alumni Awards 2021.

item.title: Education leaders urged to prioritise social interaction after Welsh youngsters have their say
item.description: They may be seen as the ones least vulnerable to transmission and the negative health impacts of Covid-19, but pandemic restrictions disrupted young people’s education, physical activity and opportunities to socialise.

item.title: Swansea University doctoral student named one of Top 50 Women in Engineering
item.description: Caitlin McCall, an engineering doctoral student from Swansea University, has been named one of 2021’s Top 50 Women in Engineering (WE50) by the Women's Engineering Society (WES).

item.title: £700k support to expand primary care medical training in West Wales
item.description: A Swansea University initiative dedicated to creating the next generation of Welsh medical professionals has been given a major boost by Welsh Government.

item.title: “Best day I have ever had” – Technocamps STEM Academy delights and inspires pupils after school closures
item.description: As part of Technocamps’ STEM Academy this Summer, the Welsh Government-funded outreach project hosted a week of fun activities in Swansea to inspire, motivate and engage young people in STEM subjects.

item.title: Bird malaria spreading via global hotspots
