item.description: Bird species across the globe are suffering and dying from a type of malaria and, while these strains are not infectious to humans, they’re spreading quickly through global transmission hotspots.

item.title: Wildlife thriving at new community garden
item.description: A community garden created with help from Swansea University bioscientists has blossomed into a magnet for wildlife.

item.title: Reducing direct contacts can help lower risk of Covid transmission and help keep schools open
item.description: The more direct contacts primary school staff had with people outside their household, the greater the likelihood of Covid-19 cases in school and self-reported symptoms, such as colds.

item.title: Closing educational engagement gap for young carers is key to improving health and wellbeing of future generations
item.description: In collaboration with Swansea University, a new study published today by Public Health Wales evidences the negative impact that caring responsibilities have on educational participation in those aged 16-22, and how this has the greatest impact on those living in the most deprived areas.

item.title: Trans and DSD athletes - Swansea experts at forefront of research on eligibility criteria
item.description: Elite athletes who are trans gender, like New Zealand Olympic weightlifter Laurel Hubbard, or have differences in sex development (DSD), like South African runner Caster Semenya, have been in the global spotlight.

item.title: Venom contributed to the species diversity of insects and fishes
item.description: The extraordinary diversity of insects and fishes, the most species-rich invertebrate and vertebrate groups in the animal kingdom, is partly due to the origin of venom, a new study of their evolution has revealed.

item.title: Carbon capture research gets a boost
item.description: Scientists at the Energy Safety Research Institute of Swansea University have received a boost to their research into climate change solutions following funding from the UK Carbon Capture and Storage Research Centre.

item.title: 604,000 calls to 999 for Covid in first wave, with care provided varying widely across the UK - national ambulance survey
item.description: Over 600,000 emergency calls to 999 during the first wave of the pandemic were for suspected Covid, with ambulances sent in almost 80% of cases and 43% of patients being conveyed to hospital, a major new survey of UK ambulance services has shown.

item.title: How to cut Covid risk in the car - researchers reveal best methods
item.description: Researchers at Swansea University have laid out a step-by-step guide to reduce exposure to the coronavirus when travelling by car, including some important and surprising advice on opening windows.

item.title: First responders and NHS staff proved more resilient during early days of pandemic
item.description: A new study has revealed first responders and healthcare workers experienced lower levels of psychological distress than the general population during the first lockdown.

item.title: New algorithm can help improve cellular materials design
item.description: New research published in Scientific Reports has revealed that a simple but robust algorithm can help engineers to improve the design of cellular materials that are used in a variety of diverse applications ranging from defence, bio-medical to smart structures and the aerospace sector.

item.title: Study shows public torn over the issue of Covid-19 vaccinations in children
item.description: New research by a Swansea University expert has highlighted just how torn members of the public are over whether children should be offered Covid-19 vaccines.

item.title: Student wins £1000 from Santander to support freelance gaming business
item.description: A first-year student who also works as a freelance game moderator has won a £1000 award from the Santander UK Freelancer scheme to help support his work.

item.title: Shout out for innovative new children’s video about fish migration
item.description: An international team led by Swansea University has come up with a novel way of teaching youngsters about fish migration.

item.title: Chemistry researcher’s award to support work that can help improve sustainable technology
item.description: A Swansea chemistry researcher has been awarded a scholarship to support his work on molecules known as “radicals”, which could help improve the efficiency and performance of technologies such as solar cells and batteries.

item.title: Outdoor healthcare and greener hospitals – Swansea team to evaluate benefits
item.description: Researchers from the School of Psychology have been awarded funding to examine the potential health benefits of creating sustainable eco-friendly hospitals and providing healthcare outdoors.

item.title: New ways to support people with long Covid to be evaluated by Swansea experts
item.description: Personalised rehabilitation programmes for patients with long Covid are to be developed as part of a new research project involving Swansea University health economists, which has just been awarded £1.1 million of UK government funding.

item.title: University hosts pioneering £2.5m research into 3D bioprinting using human cells
item.description: A world-leading £2.5 million plus research programme to revolutionise surgeons’ ability to reconstruct nose and ear cartilage in patients affected by facial difference has been launched at Swansea University.

item.title: Swansea University contributes to Eisteddfod AmGen 2021 online programme
item.description: Swansea University will sponsor the Babell Lên (literary pavilion) and contribute to several online sessions as part of this year’s Eisteddfod AmGen programme.

item.title: AgorIP helping to bring psychologist’s book series to a wider audience
item.description: A series of books to help support the psychological needs of people living with diabetes have been given a major boost by experts at Swansea University.

item.title: Pharmacist with a passion for healthcare change wins prestigious scholarship
item.description: A pharmacist who grew up in a community where access to basic healthcare supplies was a luxury has secured a scholarship to further her studies at Swansea University.

item.title: Remote sensing techniques help treat and manage hollow forests
item.description: Using advanced remote sensing techniques can help the early detection of oak tree decline and control many other forest diseases worldwide, says new research from Swansea University.

item.title: Swansea student interviews sporting greats while helping others achieve their career goals
item.description: When Robert Yarr left secondary school, he viewed university as purely a necessity. However, with the help of the Swansea Employability Academy (SEA), he has been able to study whilst developing his passion for sports journalism.

item.title: A family fun quest across Swansea helping the community explore underwater environments
item.description: Throughout July, FIRE Lab's art-science creations, Underwater Realm, are being exhibited in Swansea's Square Peg Coffee House and mark the starting point of a QR code treasure hunt around the city.

item.title: Swansea University ranked 12th in the UK for student satisfaction
item.description: Swansea University has been ranked 12th for overall student satisfaction in the 2021 National Student Survey (NSS).

item.title: Signs of hope for teen mental health but loneliness and anxiety remain high
item.description: The easing of lockdown seems to have helped many British teenagers’ mental health but loneliness and anxiety remain extremely common, according to new research by the Mental Health Foundation and Swansea University.

item.title: Nature’s flood defences: coastal wetlands offer more protection than previously thought, new research on estuaries shows
item.description: Coastal wetlands – such as salt marshes - provide even more flood protection than previously thought, reducing the risk to lives and homes in estuaries, a new study has revealed.

item.title: David Suchet stars in Swansea professor’s new drama
item.description: Sir David Suchet, star of the famous Poirot TV series takes the lead role in a new drama written by Swansea University’s Director of Creative Writing, Professor David Britton.

item.title: New study provides a solution for engineering cellular materials
item.description: A new study by a Swansea University academic has announced a new mathematical formula that will help engineers assess the point at which cellular materials, which are used a wide range of applications ranging from aerospace to the construction industry, will bend and buckle.

item.title: Report released on the impact of the pandemic on the Welsh language
item.description: Swansea University's Academi Hywel Teifi has published a follow-up report to its conference ‘A Worry or an Opportunity: Welsh in the “New Normal”’, which was held in March this year.

item.title: Professor becomes first UK winner of prestigious computer education honour
item.description: A Swansea University academic has received a double accolade for his expertise at teaching Information Systems.

item.title: Swansea University student helping to promote race equality in Wales
item.description: A Swansea student is speaking out about her own experiences of racism to help ensure Wales becomes a better place to live.

item.title: New film series exploring issues facing Wales to be launched
item.description: A new documentary film series that explores the challenges facing Wales, drawing on academic research, is to be launched at a virtual event - open to all - by a Welsh Government Cabinet Minister.

item.title: Festival returns online to share wonders of science
item.description: Swansea University scientists will be sharing their expertise with the community at a special weekend of online events.

item.title: Unique digital art project on show at city gallery
item.description: A University art project aimed at highlighting the connection between art and science features in a new exhibition at Swansea’s Mission Gallery.

item.title: PhD student wins Swansea University Three Minute Thesis competition with research into combatting MS
item.description: A PhD student from Swansea University Medical School has won the Swansea University Three Minute Thesis (3MT) competition.

item.title: Oriel Science inspires pupils' community spirit during first school visit to new exhibition space
item.description: Swansea University's Oriel Science has welcomed the first school to visit its new city centre exhibition venue.

item.title: Swansea University student and tech experts help Downing Street launch net-zero campaign
item.description: On 4 June 2021, Llanelli-based tech experts Vindico ICS Ltd represented small businesses at Downing Street to launch Together for Our Planet, a nationwide campaign that will roll out across the UK in the run-up to the UN Climate Change Conference (COP26) in November.

item.title: Swansea University appoints Interim Registrar and Chief Operating Officer
item.description: Swansea University has announced the appointment of Niamh Lamond as Interim Registrar and Chief Operating Officer.

item.title: New contracts see University remain at the heart of Welsh healthcare education for the future
item.description: Swansea University will continue to play a vital role in training the healthcare workforce of the future for the next decade.

item.title: University to welcome new Pro-Vice Chancellor with international focus
item.description: Swansea University is to welcome Professor Judith Lamie to its senior leadership team as a new Pro-Vice Chancellor with responsibility for the university’s international portfolio.

item.title: Swansea University to hold free event encouraging adults on first steps towards higher education
item.description: A free event aimed at showing just what a university education could offer is being held in Swansea city centre on Tuesday 6 July.

item.title: New technology and partnerships to aid scientists facing critical global challenges
item.description: Swansea University and Diamond Light Source to exploit revolutionary nanoparticle beam technology.

item.title: Rhys Davies Short Story Competition shortlist announced
item.description: A children’s author, the winner of the inaugural BBC Young Writers Award, and a previous Colm Tóibín International Prize winner are among the 12 authors shortlisted for the 2021 Rhys Davies Short Story Competition.

item.title: Pharaohs, crocodile sharks and insect poo – winners of 2021 Research as Art competition announced
item.description: Seventeen stunning images, and the fascinating stories behind them – the surprise finding inside a crocodile shark, Antarctic glaciers on the move, and the unexpected uses of insect poo - have today been revealed as the winners of the 2021 Research as Art competition.

item.title: Swansea University hosts major international conference on statues and monuments
item.description: In June 2020, protesters toppled the statue of the slave trader Edward Colston from its plinth in Bristol and debates about controversial statues became front-page news in Wales and around the world. Twelve months on, those issues are the focus of a major international conference organised by academics at Swansea University.

item.title: Swansea University scoops silver Diversity and Inclusion Whatuni award
item.description: Swansea University has been recognised for its excellence in diversity and inclusion during the pandemic, winning a silver award in the 2021 Whatuni Student Choice Awards.

item.title: Pan-Wales engineering research network secures funding to continue its work
item.description: The pan-Wales research network in advanced engineering and materials, led by a Swansea University Engineering Professor, has received a second round of funding which will allow it to continue its work for a further 2 years.

item.title: COVID-19 pandemic: New report details NHS innovation
item.description: Report captures learnings and innovative practice emerging from across NHS Wales in response to the COVID-19 pandemic.

item.title: Improving asphalt road pavement with nano-engineered particles
item.description: Warm mix asphalt (WMA) is gaining attention in the asphalt industry as an eco-friendly and sustainable technology.

item.title: Football star shares first-hand experience of life with diabetes at online Q&A
item.description: Former Swansea City star and USA international footballer Jordan Morris is teaming up with Swansea University to discuss how he manages to combine a career in top-flight sport with type 1 diabetes.

item.title: Swansea academic publishes in elite mathematical journal
item.description: A paper by Swansea University’s Grigory Garkusha has just been published by one of the world’s most prestigious mathematical journals.

item.title: Medical School set to welcome students as Canadian partnership grows
item.description: Swansea University is building on its successful collaboration with Trent University in Canada to launch an additional opportunity for transatlantic study.

item.title: Squirty Voter: An innovative COVID-19 compliant way to collect public feedback
item.description: Researchers at Swansea University’s Computational Foundry are sharing a new, low cost invention which combines the concept of traditional public voting machines and automatic hand sanitiser dispensers.

item.title: Lecturer honoured for exceptional contribution to pharmacology teaching
item.description: A Swansea University Medical School academic has been honoured for his innovative approach and contribution to teaching.

item.title: New partnership launched with University of Canberra in Sport and Exercise Sciences
item.description: Sport and exercise science experts from Swansea and the University of Canberra (UC) in Australia have launched an official partnership which will see them collaborate on research, teaching and student exchanges.

item.title: Latest QS World University Rankings 2022 see Swansea University climb to 440th
item.description: Swansea University has been named as the world’s 440th best university, according to the latest edition of the world’s leading university ranking and has achieved the largest ranking improvement in Wales this year.

item.title: Swansea University breaks into Complete University Guide top 30
item.description: Swansea University has achieved its highest ever position in the Complete University Guide League Tables 2022 – and has broken into the top 30.

item.title: New survey to explore the health and wellbeing of headteachers and senior staff during Covid-19
item.description: Researchers at Swansea University are calling on headteachers and senior leadership staff to complete a survey about their experiences during the Covid-19 pandemic.

item.title: Ecotourism expert’s key role at UN World Oceans Day virtual summit
item.description: Swansea University ecotourism expert Carl Cater is taking part in global event to mark United Nations World Oceans Day on Tuesday, June 8.

item.title: Author Margaret Atwood and poet laureate Simon Armitage join Free virtual programme exploring creative approaches to climate crisis
item.description: Taliesin Arts Centre is to host Everything Change, a series of discussions and events exploring the roles creativity, adaptive thinking and storytelling can play in overcoming the challenges of the climate crisis.

item.title: Student volunteers create personalised packs to support local community during pandemic
item.description: As part of their commitment to providing key support throughout the pandemic, Swansea University student volunteers have created activity packs for children, young people, and disabled adults within the community.

item.title: New study into green tea’s potential to help tackle Covid-19
item.description: As India continues to be ravaged by the pandemic, a Swansea University academic is investigating how green tea could give rise to a drug capable of tackling Covid-19.

item.title: Engineering students can’t get to the lab, so tutors send lab to the students
item.description: Engineering students have been getting vital hands-on experience, despite laboratories being off-limits due to COVID, thanks to home lab kits developed and sent out by their lecturers.

item.title: Swansea University renews Swans front of shirt sponsorship for 2021-22 season
item.description: Swansea University will renew its front of shirt sponsorship with Swansea City for the forthcoming 2021-22 season.

item.title: University experts’ Covid-related research
item.description: Swansea University researchers are helping to develop wider understanding of Covid-19 in addition to their important focus on vaccines.

item.title: £20k MBA scholarship awarded to outstanding student
item.description: A student from Jamaica has beaten off the challenge of 40 other hopefuls to win a coveted, full £20k scholarship to study at Swansea University.

item.title: Professor is new head of Government advisory body
item.description: A leading Swansea University scientist has been appointed to head a key Government advisory committee by Health Secretary Matt Hancock.

item.title: Study sheds new light on link between Covid pressures and suicidal thoughts
item.description: New research has revealed more about the impact Covid-19 and lockdown has had on the mental health and wellbeing of people in Wales.

item.title: Swansea University announces GwyddonLe-T programme at Urdd Eisteddfod
item.description: Swansea University is sponsoring and coordinating one of the main attractions of the online Urdd Eisteddfod-T once again this year, the GwyddonLe, offering a series of live events, resources, and videos of entertaining educational activities for the whole family.

item.title: Hollywood actor Michael sheen joins Swansea University’s programme of events at Hay Festival
item.description: Swansea University will host a series of events at this year’s Hay Festival, which brings writers and readers together for an inspiring array of conversations, debates, workshops and performances online, from Wednesday 26 May to Sunday 6 June.

item.title: How vaccine passports, conspiracy theories and Covid echo chambers influence vaccine delay
item.description: A study by researchers from Swansea University shows that conspiracy theories, a distrust in in government and Covid echo chambers are among the factors leading to vaccine delay.

item.title: Safety first – how a pigeon’s journey home reveals more about their flight patterns
item.description: How does a lone pigeon get back home? Does it choose the fastest, the easiest or the safest route?

item.title: A safer, greener way to make solar cells
item.description: Scientists at SPECIFIC Innovation and Knowledge Centre, Swansea University, have found a way to replace the toxic, unsustainable solvents currently needed to make the next generation of solar technology.

item.title: Learned Society of Wales honours Swansea University academics
item.description: Two academics from Swansea University are among the latest recipients of the Learned Society of Wales’ medals, announced at the Society’s AGM on Wednesday, 19th May.

item.title: Swansea University students write the Urdd’s 2021 Peace and Goodwill Message
item.description: A group of Swansea University students has written this year’s Peace and Goodwill Message, which focuses on equality for women and girls.

item.title: Researchers reveal new tool to help prevent suicide
item.description: A team of Welsh academics has developed a new method of supporting health professionals to make clinical decisions about people who may be at risk of taking their own lives.

item.title: Swansea University’s Oriel Science opens new city centre venue
item.description: Swansea University’s Oriel Science is back with a new exhibition venue in the heart of Swansea city centre and will open its doors on Saturday 22nd May.

item.title: Swansea Cyber Security Masters course is certified for top quality by UK expert body
item.description: Swansea University’s MSc in Cyber Security has received official certification for its quality from the National Cyber Security Centre (NCSC), which is part of GCHQ and is the UK’s leading expert body in the field.

item.title: Dylan Thomas: thousands of items feature in new online digital archive
item.description: A digital collection of manuscripts, notebooks and photographs relating to the Welsh writer Dylan Thomas is now available free online, thanks to an international collaboration.

item.title: Raven Leilani wins Swansea University Dylan Thomas Prize 2021 for her 'fearless' debut, Luster
item.description: New Yorker Raven Leilani has been awarded one of the world’s largest literary prizes for young writers – the Swansea University Dylan Thomas Prize – for her ‘fearless’ debut Luster, a provocatively page-turning and painfully funny novel about what it means to be a black millennial woman in America.

item.title: Swansea takes lead as new mental health research hub launches
item.description: Swansea University is playing a leading role in a new UK-wide consortium to bring together vital mental health data.

item.title: Research reveals new approach to understanding our wellbeing
item.description: The ability to connect and feel a sense of belonging are basic human needs but new Swansea University research has examined how these are determined by more than just our personal relationships.

item.title: Swansea expert named by World Anti-Doping Agency as Chair of their Ethics Expert Advisory Group
item.description: The World Anti-Doping Agency (WADA) has announced that Professor Michael McNamee of Sport and Exercise Sciences has been appointed as Chair of WADA’s ethics expert advisory group

item.title: Printed workbooks make STEM subjects accessible to all during school closures
item.description: Technocamps, a Swansea University outreach project, is supporting children across Wales who don’t have internet access by producing 3,000 activity workbooks and resources so they can work at home on STEM subjects (Science, Technology, Engineering and Maths) if their school is closed because of COVID-19.

item.title: One in nine adults struggled with mental health during pandemic, find researchers
item.description: A Swansea University professor has taken part in research that shows one in nine adults consistently had very poor or deteriorating mental health during the first six months of the Covid-19 pandemic.

item.title: Nanoplastics and other harmful pollutants found within disposable face masks
item.description: Swansea University scientists have uncovered potentially dangerous chemical pollutants that are released from disposable face masks when submerged in water.

item.title: Student entrepreneurs get boost for their business ideas at the Big Pitch
item.description: Enterprising students earned a major boost for their business ideas at the University’s annual Big Pitch Competition, sponsored by Santander Universities.

item.title: New chapter for Harriet as she launches children’s book series
item.description: A Swansea University graduate hopes her new children’s book will be the first in a series of resources aimed at taking young readers on sensory journey.

item.title: Study reveals extent of human impact on the world’s plant-life
item.description: A Swansea University bioscientist has taken part in research which has shed new light on the impact of humans on Earth’s biodiversity.

item.title: Swansea University shortlisted in the Working Families Best Practice Awards
item.description: The finalists for the annual Best Practice Awards have been announced today by work-life balance charity Working Families

item.title: New vote advice website launched for 2021 Senedd election
item.description: A new interactive website has been launched to help voters in the upcoming Senedd election identify how their policy preferences line up with the stances of political parties and candidates.

item.title: Swansea University Academics Honoured by Learned Society of Wales
item.description: Ten Swansea University academics are among the new entrants to the Learned Society of Wales’ Fellowship.

item.title: University celebrates 50,000 Santander Cycle journeys
item.description: Swansea University is celebrating a landmark 50,000 journeys being made by the Santander Cycles bike share scheme – proving how the scheme has gone from strength to strength in the city since its launch in 2018.

item.title: Academi Hywel Teifi sponsors Llais stage at this year’s Tafwyl festival
item.description: As the Tafwyl festival celebrates its fifteenth anniversary this year, Swansea University's Academi Hywel Teifi will be sponsoring the festival's Llais (Voice) platform once again, and will present a series of virtual literary events for people of all ages.

item.title: Swansea University historian shortlisted for prestigious Wolfson History Prize 2021
item.description: A Swansea University historian has been shortlisted for the Wolfson History Prize 2021, the UK’s most prestigious history writing prize, which celebrates the best historical non-fiction titles from the past year and carries a £40,000 prize.

item.title: Academic’s new book celebrates a lifelong sporting passion
item.description: A Swansea University lecturer’s latest book was not only a labour of love but also a chance to pay tribute to the man who inspired his passion for the game of cricket.

item.title: Lecturer named UK’s top Higher Education biosciences teacher
item.description: A Swansea University academic who helped pioneer engaging ways of teaching science remotely during the pandemic has been honoured by the Royal Society of Biology.

item.title: University software engineer wins major Fellowship award
item.description: A Swansea University Senior Research Software Engineer has been awarded the first Fellowship offered by the Science & Technology Facilities Council (STFC) in Research Software Engineering.

item.title: Researchers develop new method for putting quantum correlations to the test
item.description: Physicists from Swansea University are part of an international research collaboration which has identified a new technique for testing the quality of quantum correlations.

item.title: Data science for charities: student-led programme gives valuable insight to non-profits
item.description: The first event of the DataAid programme saw 25 PhD students, including 9 from Swansea University, work together with three UK charities to solve real-world data problems. The charities involved were The Fairtrade Foundation, The Diana Award and Chance to Shine.

item.title: New study to evaluate how well shielding against COVID-19 works
item.description: Shielding vulnerable people has been central to the response to COVID-19, but how well does it work?   A Swansea University research team are to examine the evidence, to see what lessons can be learned for the future.

item.title: Swansea University academic receives Outstanding Contribution award for enhancing tutoring at UK universities
item.description: A Swansea University academic has received an Outstanding Contribution award in recognition of his work in supporting the United Kingdom Advising and Tutoring Association (UKAT).

item.title: Scientists at CERN successfully laser-cool antimatter for the first time
item.description: Swansea University physicists, as leading members of the ALPHA collaboration at CERN, have demonstrated laser cooling of antihydrogen atoms for the first time. The groundbreaking achievement produces colder antimatter than ever before and enables an entirely new class of experiments, helping scientists learn more about antimatter in future.

item.title: Research reveals the persistent danger after landscape fires
item.description: Every year, an estimated four percent of the world's vegetated land surface burns, leaving more than 250 megatons of carbonized plants behind.

item.title: SAIL Databank reveals no cases of rare form of clotting in COVID19 vaccinated population of Wales
item.description: New research finds no cases of a rare blood disorder have been identified in the COVID-19 vaccinated population of Wales.

item.title: New expertise added to University pharmacy team
item.description: Swansea University has welcomed a trio of new staff as the countdown continues to the launch of its first pharmacy programme in September.

item.title: Global warming helps invasive species flourish - study models likely combined effects on ecosystems
item.description: Increased global temperatures help invasive species establish themselves in ecosystems, new research led by a Swansea University bioscientist has shown.

item.title: Student awarded grant from nationwide development initiative
item.description: A Swansea University student is one of only four students nationwide who has secured a grant of £10,000 after taking part in a new personal and professional development learning initiative.

item.title: Swansea University Dylan Thomas Prize 2021 reveals diverse and inclusive shortlist of bold new voices
item.description: The shortlist for one of the world’s largest literary prizes for young writers – the Swansea University Dylan Thomas Prize – is announced today, featuring a raft of bold new voices that challenge expectations in a compelling exploration of survival, identity, belonging and what it means to be ‘other’ in our world today.

item.title: Funding for cutting edge equipment to help reach net zero target
item.description: Swansea University has been awarded £4.8m UK Government funding for cutting-edge equipment to manufacture silicon carbide (SiC) power semiconductor devices that will create more efficient power electronics for homes, transportation and industry, and help to deliver on the nation’s net zero ambitions.

item.title: Researchers launch online marketplace to improve manufacturing supply chain
item.description: A Swansea University research team have launched a new digital platform that will transform the way supply chains operate within the manufacturing industry.

item.title: Researchers launch survey to examine face mask usage during Covid-19 pandemic
item.description: A team of researchers at Swansea University are calling on members of the public to complete a survey about their experiences of wearing face masks during the Covid-19 pandemic.

item.title: Researchers develop COVID-19 detection kit for wastewater
item.description: Researchers from Swansea University have developed a unique device that can detect COVID-19 in common wastewater.

item.title: New supercomputer will accelerate research into uses of artificial intelligence
item.description: A supercomputer that can perform 15,000 trillion operations per second, making it 15,000 times more powerful than a desktop PC, is to be installed at Swansea University, where it will support research on artificial intelligence (AI) in fields from engineering to medicine.

item.title: Swansea University supports National Day of Reflection on 23 March 2021
item.description: Swansea University’s Fulton House will be lit up in yellow on Tuesday 23 March as part of a national day to remember those who have died during the Covid-19 pandemic and to support those who've been bereaved.

item.title: Three shortlisted entries for 2021 St David Awards involve Swansea University
item.description: Three of the shortlisted entries for this year’s St David Awards, the national awards of Wales, involve Swansea University.

item.title: A year of everyday pandemic experiences shared in University’s unique new digital archive
item.description: An online digital archive containing material documenting hundreds of people’s experiences of Covid-19 will be launched at Swansea University on March 23 – the anniversary of the first UK lockdown.

item.title: New funding secures support for university
item.description: Swansea University is to dedicate £1.5 million in extra funding to three initiatives that will help to maintain capacity and aid wider economic recovery in the context of the impact of the Covid-19 pandemic.

item.title: New pledge to support life science innovation in Wales and Ireland
item.description: Life science experts from Swansea University are looking forward to playing a key role in plans to forge even closer links between Wales and Ireland.

item.title: A time of change; A time to change? A CADR Conference
item.description:
23rd - 25th March 2021

The Centre for Ageing and Dementia Research (CADR) will be welcoming academics, professionals and the public to its first Zoom conference to coincide with the anniversary of the start of national lockdown.

item.title: Warning over effects of pandemic on young people’s mental health
item.description: Triggers for self-harm and poor mental health are aggravated by pandemic restrictions, according to experts.

item.title: Wildflowers for wellbeing? Green-fingered citizen scientists sought for UK study
item.description: A bunch of amateur gardeners from across the UK is needed for a new research project, involving Swansea University, which looks at the benefits of growing plants, volunteering and online communities – and NHS hospitals will end up blooming from it too.

item.title: Researchers trial assessing renewable energy sites with drones
item.description: Researchers from Swansea University are part of a project to trial a new method of measuring tidal currents which could revolutionise the marine renewables industry.

item.title: Wales continues to pioneer in Value-Based Health Care with landmark charter
item.description: Welsh Government, Pfizer, Swansea University and Life Sciences Hub Wales have all signed a ground-breaking charter that reflects their shared beliefs in driving the adoption and delivery of Value-Based Health Care in Wales.

item.title: University prepares to welcome first pharmacy students with new facilities
item.description: Work has begun to create £2.1 million state-of-the-art facilities for Swansea University’s new pharmacy courses.

item.title: Prisons in a pandemic – new funding to examine impact on prisoner well-being and mental health
item.description: The impact of Covid restrictions on prisoners and prisons is to be examined in a new Swansea-led research project, which has been awarded £251,240 by the Economic and Social Research Council, to see what lessons can be learned.

item.title: Study examines impact of Covid-19 on children’s physical activity and mental health
item.description: New Swansea University research is examining the impact Covid-19 is having on the physical activity, mental health and wellbeing of children in Wales.

item.title: Swansea University report makes official recommendations to the Welsh Government to tackle Wales’ second homes crisis
item.description: The author of a new report commissioned by the Welsh Government’s Minister for Mental Health, Wellbeing and Welsh Language has made 12 policy recommendations to the Welsh Government to address the second homes crisis in Wales and its impact on Welsh speaking communities.

item.title: University joining the drive to reduce food waste
item.description: Swansea University is giving its backing to the UK’s first ever Food Waste Action Week.

item.title: First Minister opens Swansea University’s Morgan Advanced Studies Institute
item.description: The Right Honourable Mark Drakeford MS, First Minister of Wales, today (Friday, 26 February) officially opened Swansea University’s Morgan Advanced Studies Institute (MASI) during a virtual ceremony.

item.title: New study highlights importance of context to physical theories
item.description: A Swansea University scientist’s research into the geometrical characteristics of a physical theories is highlighted in a new paper.

item.title: The way a fish swims reveals a lot about its personality, say scientists
item.description: Personality has been described in all sorts of animal species, from ants to apes. Some individuals are shy and sedentary, while others are bold and active. Now a new study published in Ecology and Evolution has revealed that the way a fish swims tells us a lot about its personality.

item.title: Global research into how the vulnerable have been hit by official responses to Covid-19
item.description: Academics from Swansea University are part of an international study exploring the impact of Covid-19 governmental responses on vulnerable groups.

item.title: High fructose diets could cause immune system damage - new research
item.description: New research by Swansea scientists in collaboration with scientists at the University of Bristol and the Francis Crick Institute in London has indicated that consuming a diet high in the sugar fructose might prevent the proper functioning of peoples’ immune systems in ways that has, until now, largely been unknown.

item.title: Nursing students’ high-tech help for hospital patients
item.description: Patients at a west Wales hospital have been given a helping hand to stay in touch with loved ones by Swansea University nursing students.

item.title: Your chance to be part of research into how a nasal spray could help combat Covid-19
item.description: Swansea University is looking for volunteers from South Wales to be part of vital research into how an over-the-counter nasal spray could help protect against Covid-19.

item.title: Major grant to develop oats as a healthy food product
item.description: A major European grant has been awarded to partners in Ireland and Wales, including Swansea University, to research the development of oats as a climate-resistant crop and a healthy food product.

item.title: Paramedic students vaccinated as they continue to help support services
item.description: Swansea University paramedic students have received their coronavirus vaccine as they continue to work on the NHS frontline.

item.title: A tribute to Professor Hywel Francis
item.description: Hywel Francis, adult educator, historian, activist and parliamentarian, who has died at the age of 74, is mourned by his innumerable friends within and beyond Swansea University.

item.title: The Coleg Cymraeg appoints new Higher Education Ambassadors from Swansea University
item.description: The Coleg Cymraeg has appointed five new ambassadors from Swansea University for 2021 to encourage more prospective students to take an interest in Welsh-medium higher education.

item.title: People with asthma in poorest areas are 50% more likely to die than those in richest areas
item.description: People with asthma in Wales’s most deprived areas are 50% more likely to be admitted to hospital and to die from asthma compared with those in the least deprived areas, a new five-year study of over 100,000 people has revealed.

item.title: Research reveals those self-isolating need mental health and financial support
item.description: More than half of people who had to self-isolate felt it negatively affected their mental health with more than a quarter saying it negatively affected their income, Swansea University research has revealed.

item.title: Experts combine forces to keep children safe online
item.description: Swansea University is spearheading the fight against online child sexual exploitation after securing major funding for an innovative new project focused on online child sexual grooming.

item.title: New joint project aims to CONNECT students at universities
item.description: A new joint project that aims to support students experiencing loneliness and isolation has been launched by Swansea University and the University of Wales Trinity Saint David (UWTSD).

item.title: Population Data Science Director recognised in data industry influence awards
item.description: Professor David Ford, Director of the Population Data Science Group at Swansea University, has been recognised amongst the most influential people in data and analytics in the 2021 edition of the DataIQ 100.

item.title: Green Hydrogen Research Helps Industry Reduce Carbon Emissions
item.description: A collaboration between researchers at the Energy Safety Research Institute at Swansea University and cement producer Hanson UK has seen the installation of a new green hydrogen demonstration unit at the company’s Regen GGBS plant in Port Talbot, South Wales.

item.title: Applications open for new Swansea University scholarship which commemorates Hywel Teifi Edwards' contribution to Welsh Culture
item.description: Swansea University's Academi Hywel Teifi is calling on students who want to study for a postgraduate research degree through the medium of Welsh to apply for a new scholarship in memory of Professor Hywel Teifi Edwards.

item.title: Children’s fingers point to mothers’ income level and diseases that begin in the womb
item.description: Low-income mothers feminize their children in the womb by adjusting their hormones, whereas high-income mothers masculinize their children, a major study based on finger length, led by a Swansea University expert, has found.

item.title: Hillary Clinton extends scholarship programme in partnership with Sky and Swansea University
item.description: Former US Secretary of State Hillary Clinton has announced that the Hillary Rodham Clinton Global Challenges programme at Swansea University has been extended to a further five scholars.

item.title: Cardiac patients with diabetes can exercise more safely thanks to new expert guidance
item.description: Cardiac patients who also have diabetes will be able to do their rehabilitation exercises more safely, thanks to the world’s first guidance on the subject, which has been published by international experts including a Swansea University academic.

item.title: New chance to share experiences of living during a pandemic
item.description: As the pandemic continues to dominate our lives, people are being asked to share their experiences as part of ongoing research into how the Welsh are coping with coronavirus.

item.title: Experts put new method of analysing children’s play to the test
item.description: How to study the stages children go through as they play together has been highlighted in new research by a Swansea University academic.

item.title: University keeps more than 250 pupils reading during latest lockdown
item.description: Year 7 pupils at two local schools have been encouraged to read and boost their literacy during lockdown, thanks to a Swansea University project.

item.title: Controls needed to stop zebra mussels invading Great Britain
item.description: New research by Swansea University scientists found that boat ramps facilitate the dispersal of the highly invasive zebra mussel (Dreissena polymorpha). To contain the dispersion of this invasive species Dr Marta Rodriguez-Rey and co-authors suggest in the new study, that strict control measures and target monitoring around boat ramps should be implemented.

item.title: Experts call for more pragmatic approach to higher education teaching
item.description: Millions of students around the world could benefit if their educators adopted a more flexible and practical approach, say Swansea University experts.

item.title: Remembering disasters in Wales and France - volunteers needed for new study
item.description: A Swansea University researcher is appealing for Welsh volunteers to share their memories of past disasters for a new study that will look at how these memories are processed by people living in Wales and in France.

item.title: Global experts unite to discuss historic dream of Freud’s patient Dora
item.description: Swansea University sleep expert Mark Blagrove is hosting special event to commemorate a significant moment in the history of dream analysis.

item.title: Swansea University and Faradair Aerospace strengthen relationship for UK aerospace revival
item.description: Swansea University and Faradair Aerospace are to expand their relationship with the British company’s commitment to bring back large-scale aircraft production to the UK and deliver 300 home-designed, sustainable aircraft for regional air mobility and special missions by 2030.

item.title: Award-winner Tirion now tackling her next challenge – becoming a midwife
item.description: Rugby coach Tirion Thomas was delighted to be honoured for her dedication to sport but now she enjoys preparing for her future career just as much as for the next match.

item.title: Spitting cobras evolved painful venom for defence, possibly against ancestral humans
item.description: The ability of some cobras to spit their venom, unique amongst snakes, evolved as a defence mechanism to inflict pain rather than to catch prey, new research involving a Swansea University expert has revealed.

item.title: Six-fold rise in brain pressure disorder linked with obesity and deprivation
item.description: A brain pressure disorder that especially affects women, causing severe headaches and sometimes permanent sight loss, has risen six-fold in 15 years, and is linked to obesity and deprivation, a new study by Swansea University researchers has shown.

item.title: Researchers show Irish soil can offer more hope in fight against antibiotic resistance
item.description: Scientists who highlighted the bug-busting properties of bacteria in Northern Irish soil have made another exciting discovery in the quest to discover new antibiotics.

item.title: Swansea University Dylan Thomas prize 2021: Debuts and female voices dominate longlist
item.description: The international longlist for one of the world’s largest literary prizes for young writers – the Swansea University Dylan Thomas Prize – is announced today, featuring a record number of nine debut writers.

item.title: Test, Trace and Protect in Wales: call for study participants to help better understand what support people need to self-isolate
item.description: Researchers from Swansea University have been commissioned by the Senedd to explore people’s experiences of being contacted by Test, Trace, Protect (TTP) and told to self-isolate.

item.title: More acclaim for Copperopolis – involving communities in Swansea’s history
item.description: The Copperopolis project, which is at the heart of regenerating Hafod-Morfa copper works, has been selected as an example of how universities across Wales are working with their communities, creating social and economic benefits.

item.title: Swansea team help company recycle old products into new toner cartridges
item.description: The EU-Funded ASTUTE 2020 operation based at Swansea University has provided industrial Research, Development, and Innovation (RD&I) support to help Brother Industries (U.K) Ltd. produce their first Brother branded toner cartridge manufactured from recycled materials recovered from End of Life products.

item.title: Researcher honoured for work seeking sustainable solutions
item.description: A Swansea University researcher has received international recognition for his work in the field of industrial decarbonisation.

item.title: Active Buildings to be constructed in India, bringing clean solar energy to off-grid communities
item.description: Active Buildings, which generate, store and release their own solar energy, are to be constructed in India, helping some of the 600,000 villages in the country struggling with electricity supply.

item.title: Alcohol research study wins charity grant support
item.description: A Swansea University project has won funding to investigate the use of alcohol among people from Gypsy, Roma and Traveller backgrounds.

item.title: Swansea University developing world’s first COVID-19 ‘smart-patch’ vaccine that will measure effectiveness
item.description: Researchers at Swansea University are developing the world’s first smart vaccine device that will both deliver the COVID-19 vaccine and measure its efficacy through monitoring the body’s associated response.

item.title: Simple monitoring could reduce medicine misuse in care homes
item.description: New research from Swansea University suggests that a simple nurse- or carer-led medicines’ monitoring system can help reduce medication-related illness for people living in residential care homes – and the process takes just a few minutes per patient.

item.title: Courses win accreditation from Royal Geographical Society
item.description: Two Swansea University courses are among the first postgraduate qualifications to be awarded accreditation by the Royal Geographical Society.

item.title: Swansea professor appointed as Director of European Centre for Theoretical Nuclear Physics
item.description: Professor Gert Aarts FLSW, of Swansea University's Physics Department, has been appointed as Interim-Director of the European Centre for Theoretical Studies in Nuclear Physics and Related Areas (ECT*).

item.title: New review says ineffective ‘learning styles’ theory persists in education around the world
item.description: A new review by Swansea University reveals there is widespread belief around the world in a teaching method that is not only ineffective but may actually be harmful to learners.

item.title: Faster, greener way of producing carbon spheres could improve carbon capture technology
item.description: A fast, green and one-step method for producing porous carbon spheres, which are a vital component for carbon capture technology and for new ways of storing renewable energy, has been developed by Swansea University researchers.

item.title: Covid-19: Medical School and Wuhan partners share innovations with British Ambassador in China
item.description: Swansea University’s Medical School has strengthened its unique connection with Wuhan, by joining an online conference of health professionals, also attended by the British Ambassador in China, Caroline Wilson CMG, which has helped to shine a light on healthcare and innovation and Covid-19.

item.title: Funding boost for research collaboration studying provision of eye care in the community
item.description: A new project set up to study the best way to care for patients with long-standing eye conditions in the community has secured a major research grant.

item.title: New international research examines way of fighting back against Covid-19
item.description: Researchers at Swansea University Medical School are helping to drive forward understanding of the virus that causes Covid-19 and how it can be tackled.

item.title: Medical School course records triple exam success
item.description: Swansea University’s physician associate course is celebrating a remarkable hat trick – its students recorded a 100 per cent pass rate in the September PA National Exams for the third year running.

item.title: Fire-resistant tropical forest at brink of disappearance in Indonesian regions due to human modification
item.description: A new study led by researchers in the Geography Department at Swansea University reveals the extreme scale of loss and fragmentation of tropical forests, which once covered much of the Indonesian islands of Sumatra and Kalimantan.

item.title: Europe’s rivers are broken, but there is a fix
item.description: A new study published in Nature reveals the true extent of river fragmentation and offers some solutions.

item.title: Double delight for Tennessee after master’s distinction
item.description: A Swansea University student and world kickboxing champion is finishing 2020 on a high after graduating in her master’s.

item.title: University’s Money@CampusLife awarded Stand Alone Pledge Award 2020
item.description: Swansea University’s Money@CampusLife team have been awarded a Stand Alone Pledge award for their role in helping estranged students during Covid-19.

item.title: New study shows how microalgae could be crucial to circular economy
item.description: New Swansea University research has revealed microalgae could play a crucial role in not only successfully reusing food and farm waste on an industrial scale but also creating thousands of jobs.

item.title: Book about child Holocaust survivors makes Daily Telegraph’s book of the year list
item.description: A Swansea University academic’s latest book, about child survivors of the Holocaust, has been included in the Daily Telegraph’s list of the best history books of 2020.

item.title: Designing safer buildings - self-powered wireless sensing systems to detect cracks and damage
item.description: Researchers at Swansea University are developing an innovative approach to the design of smart buildings. A new environmentally sustainable, safer and cost-efficient model, designed at the Institute for Innovative Materials, Processing and Numerical Technologies (IMPACT), will offer an improved system for energy supply distribution to sensors in smart structures.

item.title: SUNRISE project wins Times Higher Education award
item.description: Swansea University in collaboration with international and UK institutions has lifted the International Collaboration of the Year trophy at the 16th annual Times Higher Education Awards.

item.title: Pregnant women who stop asthma medication at risk of preterm birth
item.description: A new study from Swansea University suggests that women who stop taking their asthma medication during pregnancy are at risk of giving birth prematurely and are less likely to breastfeed their babies.

item.title: £4m research funding boost for Welsh manufacturing sector
item.description: Manufacturing businesses across Wales can remain at the forefront of innovation, thanks to £4 million of EU funding announced by the Welsh Government.

item.title: Judges announced for the Swansea University Dylan Thomas Prize
item.description: The judges for the 2021 Swansea University Dylan Thomas Prize have been announced today (8 December).

item.title: Community butterfly project set to give nature a helping hand
item.description: Swansea University bioscientists are helping a community create a butterfly and wildlife garden in the heart of a Swansea village.

item.title: Smarter, greener steelmaking: three new studies to be funded by Swansea-based research programme
item.description: Three research projects that could help the steel industry become smarter and greener have been given the go-ahead as part of a national steel research programme led by Swansea University.

item.title: New funding for research on COVID-19 and cardiovascular disease
item.description: Swansea University has received £125k of funding from Health Data Research UK (HDR UK) to study the impact of the direct and indirect effects of COVID-19 on cardiovascular disease (CVD).

item.title: Researcher to deliver keynote address at unique virtual summit
item.description: Swansea University researcher Dr Lewis Francis will share his work with a global audience at an international online conference next week.

item.title: Research to improve Welsh athletes’ performance gets four-year funding boost
item.description: A Wales-wide research project that helps enhance the performance of Welsh athletes will be able to continue its work thanks to a £440,000 grant from Sport Wales.

item.title: Study reveals new findings on nature’s UV sunscreens
item.description: Swansea University research has provided a new insight into the behaviour of nature’s own UV sunscreens when they are exposed to other parts of the light spectrum.

item.title: Swansea University relaunches prestigious Rhys Davies Short Story Competition
item.description: Swansea University’s Cultural Institute is relaunching the distinguished national Rhys Davies Short Story Competition for writers from, or living in, Wales.

item.title: University cancer research progress leads to partners’ funding boost
item.description: A Swansea University project’s ground-breaking work to improve diagnosis and treatment of ovarian cancer has helped it secure more than £3 million of investment from industrial partners.

item.title: Turning waste plastic into carbon nanotubes to transmit electricity
item.description: The Welsh government is backing a cutting-edge science project at Swansea University that changes waste plastics into highly valuable compounds for the energy industries.

item.title: New engineering partnership to develop digital marketplace to improve manufacturing supply chain
item.description: A research team, led by Swansea University College of Engineering, are developing a pilot online marketplace designed to optimise manufacturing supply chain networks and create a new industry-wide business model.

item.title: University partnership ready to help new businesses make the right connections
item.description: A new collaboration is set to give student entrepreneurs a valuable networking boost as they launch their business ideas.

item.title: Older, poorer people at greater risk from adverse drug reactions
item.description: A review by Swansea University academics has found that older, poorer people who are socially distanced from their doctors or pharmacists, suﬀer more adverse drug reactions (ADRs) than the general population and that systematic monitoring is needed to protect these patients suffering from reactions which could result in over-sedation, falls, or drug-induced Parkinsonism.

item.title: New Richard Burton exhibition tells the story of an international star of stage and screen
item.description: A brand new exhibition on Richard Burton’s life reveals the man behind the headlines - the husband, father, reader, writer and passionate Welshman.

item.title: Sunlight could turn COVID waste into clean fuel – funding for new Swansea-led project
item.description: Sunlight could be used to convert hazardous medical waste into clean hydrogen fuel, using a new technique being developed by a joint Wales/India team led by Swansea University researchers.  The project has just been awarded £47,000 of funding by the Welsh Government.

item.title: New survey reveals toll Covid-19 is taking on mental health in Wales
item.description: Wales faces a wave of mental health problems in the wake of Covid-19, with younger adults, women and people from deprived areas suffering the most.

item.title: New funding making a difference to life-saving research projects
item.description: Four Swansea University projects aimed at making a life-saving difference to patients’ lives have taken a major step forward.

item.title: Scientists develop method to detect charge traps in organic semiconductors
item.description: Scientists at Swansea University have developed a very sensitive method to detect the tiny signatures of so called ‘charge traps’ in organic semiconductors.

item.title: Warmth not waste: new research will look at re-using waste heat from industry
item.description: A new project involving Swansea University researchers and Tata Steel will investigate the potential for recovering waste heat from industry so it can be re-used.

item.title: Swansea University outreach project keeps children learning during lockdown
item.description: A Swansea University outreach project has helped deliver hundreds of science workbooks to children studying at home during Wales’ fire-break lockdown.

item.title: University Navy Plaques mark the spots where memories were made
item.description: Meeting a life partner, forging friendships and enjoying a long happy career are just some of the life-changing experiences now commemorated at Swansea University.

item.title: Swansea student nurse named best in Britain
item.description: When it comes to helping patients prepare themselves for surgery, Rea Pugh-Davies is arguably one of the best around.

item.title: Designing low carbon buildings: Swansea team’s know-how gathered in new toolkit for others to use
item.description: The team that designed and built two low carbon buildings at Swansea University, which generate their own energy, is publishing a toolkit of the design principles that they used. The aim is to encourage others to construct these “Active Buildings” as it would drastically cut the UK’s carbon footprint; currently 40% of our emissions come from heating and powering our buildings.

item.title: New study examines how Covid-19 safety measures are leading to increased anxiety and avoidance behaviour
item.description: A new Swansea University study is being launched to investigate how following Covid-19 safety measures may have the unfortunate effect of making people feel less safe, leading to increased anxiety and people avoiding situations and places they once considered safe.

item.title: First study to assess risk of COVID-19 to health of domiciliary care workers in Wales
item.description: The first study to establish the risk of COVID-19 to domiciliary care workers across Wales is to launch today.

item.title: Award for physicist for work on antimatter
item.description: A Swansea University physicist has been awarded a prestigious honour by the Institute of Physics for his leadership over thirty years in the field of antimatter science.

item.title: Swansea expert helps shape world’s first agreed guidance for people with diabetes to exercise safely
item.description: A Swansea University academic has helped draw up a landmark agreement amongst international experts, setting out the world’s first standard guidance on how people with diabetes can use modern glucose monitoring devices to help them exercise safely.

item.title: Swansea nursing student scoops prestigious Most Inspirational Student of the Year award
item.description: Matt Townsend, an Adult Nursing student from Swansea University, has won the Most Inspirational Student of the Year award in this year’s Student Nursing Times Awards.

item.title: Academics call for NHS gambling treatment clinics in Wales
item.description: Swansea University academics have called for NHS gambling disorder treatment clinics to be established in Wales, as a letter published in The Lancet reveals the serious impact of problem gambling in Wales, particularly amongst younger people.

item.title: Gut hormone blocks brain cell formation and is linked to Parkinson’s dementia, Swansea research reveals
item.description: A gut hormone, ghrelin, is a key regulator of new nerve cells in the adult brain, a Swansea-led research team has discovered. It could help pave the way for new drugs to treat dementia in patients with Parkinson’s Disease.

item.title: International collaboration will lead to online archive of Dylan Thomas’ work
item.description: A digital collection of manuscripts and photographs related to the Welsh poet and writer Dylan Thomas will soon be available online thanks to an international collaboration.

item.title: University’s double success at diabetes awards
item.description: A Swansea University honorary senior tutor and a master’s student have been honoured for their dedication to diabetes care at a major UK healthcare awards.

item.title: New animation helps lymphoedema patients recognise symptoms
item.description: A new animated video has been developed by Swansea University to raise awareness of lymphoedema and help patients understand more about how their condition will be treated.

item.title: SUNRISE project shortlisted for Times Higher Education award
item.description: SUNRISE has been shortlisted for ‘International Collaboration of the Year’ in the 16th annual Times Higher Education (THE) Awards.

item.title: Professor’s new role helping to promote nanomedicine across the UK
item.description: Swansea University Medical School’s Professor Steve Conlan has taken up a key role helping to highlight UK nanomedicine research.

item.title: Boost for Wales’s lead in green solar technology thanks to EU funding
item.description: Wales can remain at the forefront of next generation solar energy technology, for applications such as remote sensors and electric vehicles, thanks to £2.5 million of EU funding announced by the Welsh Government, to continue a Swansea-led research programme.

item.title: Power to the People: Swansea expert marks prestigious award with lecture on how coated steel can harness solar energy
item.description: Coated steel can harness solar energy and cut carbon emissions, a Swansea expert will explain in a public online lecture, which is being held to mark him being awarded the prestigious Bessemer Gold Medal by the Institute of Materials, Minerals and Mining.

item.title: Researcher receives Royal Society of Biology Outreach and Engagement Award
item.description: Swansea University postdoc researcher Dr Claire Price has been recognised for her work to make science more accessible to the community in her home town.

item.title: Lockdown mental health problems amongst family carers up to 10 times higher – new study
item.description: Family carers for children and adults with intellectual disabilities have reported rates of mental health problems under lockdown that are up to 10 times higher than parents without those responsibilities, a new study has found.

item.title: Swansea University judged one of country’s best green spaces
item.description: Swansea University has once again been named among the winners of this year’s Green Flag Awards – the international mark of a quality park or green space.

item.title: New module allows engineering students to work remotely with Texas team
item.description: A group of engineering students have taken up a module run by Texas A&M University, which involves working remotely with fellow engineers overseas, thanks to a new initiative by the College of Engineering, which is founded on Swansea University’s Texas links.

item.title: Student Matt says Covid-19 taught him what it really means to be a nurse
item.description: When Swansea University nursing student Matt Townsend was given the opportunity to join the NHS frontline at the height of coronavirus crisis, he knew just what he had to do.

item.title: Welsh Government funding at ESRI for next generation PPE
item.description: Welsh Government have announced funding for the Energy Safety Research Institute (ESRI) at Swansea University to develop a unique approach to next generation Personal Protective Equipment (PPE) in the fight against viruses.

item.title: Wales Women prepare for Scotland clash at Swansea University
item.description: Wales Women are using Swansea University’s sports facilities as they prepare for their Six Nations clash against Scotland.

item.title: Being Human Festival returns for seventh year
item.description: Swansea University’s Cultural Institute has been chosen as one of four hubs for Being Human 2020, the UK’s only national festival of the humanities.

item.title: Award to fund display on cultural diversity and racism in the ancient world
item.description: An expert in ancient history and Swansea’s Egypt Centre have been jointly awarded £1100 to develop a new display on Egypt and its neighbours, which will be used for the Centre’s education programme on issues such as identity, racism and xenophobia in the ancient world.

item.title: Study shows how pandemic has hit vital breastfeeding support
item.description: A new research collaboration led by Swansea University has highlighted a lack of high-quality breastfeeding support for some families during the Covid-19 pandemic.

item.title: Swansea University announces star-studded lineup for the 2020 Swansea Science Festival
item.description: October will see the return of the Swansea Science Festival, with a host of special guests including Professor Brian Cox, Steve Backshall, Konnie Huq, Iolo Williams and Lyn Evans.

item.title: Swansea experts launch new podcast on the US 2020 presidential campaign
item.description: Researchers from Swansea University have launched a new podcast series which uses real-time data from political gambling markets to analyse the US 2020 presidential campaign.

item.title: University marks double sustainability success
item.description: Swansea University’s commitment to sustainability has led to a double achievement.

item.title: £3.7m circular economy innovation funding to support south Wales organisations
item.description: A new £3.7m project will help public service organisations in south Wales work collaboratively to develop new regional service solutions to existing circular economy challenges.

item.title: Help with groundbreaking research to find ways of improving recovery from Covid-19
item.description: Researchers exploring a new method to help people recover from Covid-19, using breathing exercises and a hand-held device, are looking for volunteers who have had Covid to help them test it. The work could benefit patients and ease the strain on the NHS.

item.title: University gets behind drive to make Wales recycling world champion
item.description: Swansea University has literally gone green to hammer home the recycling message.

item.title: Citizen scientists show that UK rivers are in pieces
item.description: New research led by Swansea University academics and assisted by citizen scientists, has found that 99% of river basins in the UK are fragmented by artificial barriers like dams, weirs, and culverts. Urgent action is needed to reconnect rivers, to ensure their long-term health, and the health of the communities around them.

item.title: University helps keep 1,100 pupils learning over lockdown
item.description: More than a thousand pupils in South Wales were given a helping hand with their studies during lockdown, thanks to a project involving Swansea University.

item.title: Participatory approach expands global instream infrastructure inventories
item.description: An international team of researchers – including some from Swansea University – have used remotely sensed data available through a Google Earth Engine to identify, map, and validate instream infrastructure such as dams, weirs, and locks across the world.

item.title: Protests, strikes and sharing a room with Paul McCartney. . .
item.description: Swansea University has seen thousands of students pass through its doors in the past 100 years, but few can have had a more eventful time than Jeffrey Temple.

item.title: University develops new Value-Based Health and Care programme
item.description: Swansea University has developed a dedicated Value-Based Health and Care (VBHC) programme in conjunction with strategic partner, Sprink Ltd, as part of its Executive Education offer.

item.title: University to develop advanced energy storage systems with new £1 million venture
item.description: A Swansea University research team from the College of Engineering are to form a new partnership with major global energy solutions provider ENSERV POWER.

item.title: Swansea health and medicine students recognised for volunteering in Covid-19 crisis
item.description: Around 1000 healthcare and medical students who have volunteered during the Covid-19 pandemic are to receive a voucher for a local business, thanks to a donation of £27,500 by Santander, through Santander Universities.

item.title: True size of prehistoric mega-shark finally revealed
item.description: A new study led by Swansea University and the University of Bristol has revealed the size of the legendary giant shark Megalodon, including fins that are as large as an adult human.

item.title: Swansea University climbs to 24th in the Guardian University Guide
item.description: Swansea University has achieved its highest ever rank in any UK league table after rising from 31st to 24th in the Guardian University Guide 2021.

item.title: Kier appointed for £30m CISM building project at Bay Campus
item.description: A new state-of-the-art facility at Swansea University that will bring together groundbreaking research with technology development in the field of semiconductor science and engineering, is one step closer with the execution of the main build contract with Kier for the Centre for Integrative Semiconductor Materials (CISM) at the Bay Campus

item.title: Distance is no hurdle as Chinese students’ language classes continue online
item.description: Chinese students, eager to prepare for Swansea University courses, have been continuing their studies - even though their teachers were more than 5,000 miles away.

item.title: Back to school safely: pupils in 12 local schools protected by Swansea Uni hand sanitiser
item.description: Children returning to lessons at 12 local schools this week are the latest people to be protected by hand sanitiser made at Swansea University, where a solar tech lab has temporarily switched production during the COVID-19 outbreak.

item.title: Study focuses on best way to handle 999 calls from Covid-19 patients
item.description: A new Swansea University study examining the best way for ambulance services to deal with suspected Covid-19 999 calls has just won major funding support.

item.title: Osteopathy services resume at Swansea’s Health and Wellbeing Academy
item.description: Swansea University’s Health and Wellbeing Academy (HWA) will begin providing osteopathy services to the general public again from Monday 7 September.

item.title: New research unveils environment drivers of ecological complexity in marine intertidal communities
item.description: Environmental conditions such as sea surface temperature and the occurrence of cold water upwelling events drive the structure of interaction networks in marine intertidal communities via their effects on species richness, according to new research.

item.title: Investment of £20m extends AgorIP project to 2023
item.description: The AgorIP Project which has helped the Welsh economy and innovation in west Wales to prosper over the last four years, has been extended to benefit all of Wales, with a total investment of more than £20m.

item.title: New report warns of massive decline in freshwater fish populations and threat to livelihoods
item.description: The Living Planet Index for Migratory Freshwater Fish, the first comprehensive global report on the status of migratory fish has revealed that there has been a 76% average decline in freshwater fish populations from 1970 to 2016 - including a staggering average decline of 93% in Europe.

item.title: Teachers welcome return to school but highlight concerns - survey
item.description: As schools reopen, a survey of primary school staff in Wales shows that they support children going back to their classes, for the sake of their education and social development, but that they also have real concerns.

item.title: Swansea University announces £230,000 funding boost for student experience
item.description: Students at Swansea University are set to benefit from a funding boost dedicated to a programme of events for new and returning students from September 2020 to February 2021.

item.title: Microneedle skin patches to administer vaccines
item.description: A revolutionary new way to give vaccines through microneedle skin patches is being tested at Swansea University, thanks to £200,000 of EU funding announced by the Welsh Government.

item.title: Study shows inbreeding reduces cooperation in banded mongooses
item.description: Inbreeding can reduce cooperation in banded mongooses according to a recent study by researchers.

item.title: Star author David Walliams backs University’s schools contest
item.description: Best-selling children’s author David Walliams has given his support to a children’s competition being held to mark Swansea University’s centenary.

item.title: Animal mummies unwrapped: hi-res 3D X-rays reveal secrets of life and death in ancient Egypt
item.description: Three mummified animals from ancient Egypt have been digitally unwrapped and dissected by researchers, using high-resolution 3D scans that give unprecedented detail about the animals’ lives – and deaths - over 2000 years ago.

item.title: University unveiled as Swansea City’s new front of shirt sponsor
item.description: Swansea University is delighted to announce that it will be the new front of shirt sponsor for Swansea City ahead of the forthcoming 2020-21 season.

item.title: Researchers capture footage of fluid behaving like a solid
item.description: Researchers from the College of Engineering have captured the moments a fluid reacts like a solid through a new method of fluid observation under pressurised conditions.

item.title: University experts leading the way on pandemic research
item.description: Four Swansea University academics are part of major new research project investigating Covid-19 and what it can teach us about coping with future pandemics.

item.title: Discovery charity awarded funding to assist in COVID-19 pandemic
item.description: Discovery SVS has been awarded two grants from Welsh Government for its work in alleviating the impact of COVID-19 in Wales and communities in Africa.

item.title: Ospreys, Wales and Lions rugby star James Hook to be University attack coach
item.description: International rugby star James Hook, who played 81 times for Wales and toured with the 2009 British and Irish Lions in South Africa, has taken up the position of Attack Coach for Swansea University rugby teams.

item.title: Project reveals how algae could play crucial role in sustainable food production
item.description: A ground-breaking Swansea University project is using microalgae to explore how to reuse waste while increasing food production.

item.title: Swansea wins bid to recruit 250 extra engineering students
item.description: Swansea University has been successful in its bid to the Department for Education (DfE) to recruit 250 extra engineering students as part of a Government drive to provide over 9,000 additional places at UK universities for courses that will deliver vital services, support the economy and create positive outcomes for students.

item.title: University welcomes new Research and Innovation Pro-Vice Chancellor
