item.description: Swansea University has welcomed a new Pro-Vice Chancellor to its senior management team, with responsibility for the University’s Research and Innovation portfolio.

item.title: Four-year delay in getting autism diagnosis, but online tools can cut the wait
item.description: Parents concerned that their child may have autism spectrum disorder (ASD) can wait up to four years for a formal diagnosis, but online assessments can help reduce these delays, two new research studies from Swansea University have shown.

item.title: Project helping to reduce burn casualties in Nepal
item.description: A burn prevention project backed by Swansea University experts has had a dramatic effect on communities in Nepal.

item.title: Swansea University’s Academi Hywel Teifi contributes to AmGen programme
item.description: The first week of August promised to be a busy one for Tregaron this year, but now that the main festival will not be held there, the Eisteddfod has launched the 2020 AmGen Festival – a project that will give people a taste of the main festival between 30 July and 8 August, all available on S4C, Radio Cymru and the Cymru Fyw website.

item.title: £6 million award to drive next-generation solar technology into new applications
item.description: A £6 million award will drive next-generation solar technology into new applications.

item.title: University innovation team helping to develop high-tech dementia aid
item.description: Swansea University innovation experts are helping to refine a high-tech device which is already making a vital difference to people living with dementia and their carers.

item.title: University centenary competition invites pupils to look to the future
item.description: Swansea University is marking its centenary by asking children to share their vision of how it would look in another 100 years.

item.title: “My degree saved me” – Natalie beats cancer to graduate
item.description: Natalie Jarvis, 27, escaped domestic abuse and has now overcome breast cancer. This week she graduates from Swansea University. In her own words, this is Natalie’s story.

item.title: New partnership set to examine how algae could be key to safer sunscreens
item.description: A Swansea University project exploring how to use algae to create the next generation of sunscreens has now teamed up with an award-winning skincare firm to help develop the idea.

item.title: Delight for Julia after 50-year wait to graduate
item.description: A retired civil servant is celebrating after graduating from Swansea University - 50 years later than planned.

item.title: Sky’s the limit for Swansea students after graduation
item.description: Two students are looking forward to their global aviation business soaring even higher after graduating from Swansea University.

item.title: The Prince of Wales records message for Swansea University’s centenary
item.description: The Prince of Wales has recorded a special video message for Swansea University as it celebrates its centenary on 19 July.

item.title: Study shows how traumatic experiences can leave their mark on a person’s eyes
item.description: New research by Welsh academics shows that a patient’s pupils can reveal if they have suffered a traumatic experience in the past.

item.title: Swansea University to use centenary celebration funds to fight Covid-19
item.description: Swansea University, which this year is marking its centenary, is to channel funds that were previously earmarked for celebration events, into fighting Covid-19 and to champion innovation.

item.title: Wonders of animal migration: how sea turtles find small, isolated islands
item.description: One of Charles Darwin’s long-standing questions on how turtles find their way to islands has been answered thanks to a pioneering study by scientists.

item.title: Swansea University ranked 6th in the UK for student satisfaction
item.description: Swansea University has been ranked sixth for overall student satisfaction in the 2020 National Student Survey (NSS).

item.title: Experts’ high-flying study puts soaring birds in spotlight
item.description: New research has revealed when it comes to flying the largest of birds don’t rely on flapping to move around. Instead they make use of air currents to keep them airborne for hours at a time.

item.title: Swansea student’s family inspire award-winning idea for disability aid
item.description: A Swansea University student’s personal experience was the inspiration for his winning entry in a nationwide hunt for the best new innovation in disability products.

item.title: University joins nationwide initiative to help students into higher education
item.description: Swansea University has signed up to be part of a new online initiative aimed at supporting students disadvantaged by the coronavirus pandemic to enter higher education.

item.title: University lecturer scoops prestigious British Science Association award
item.description: A Swansea University lecturer has won the prestigious Jacob Bronowski Award for Science and the Arts from the British Science Association.

item.title: Students step up to offer support in time of crisis
item.description: Two Swansea University students have been working to support the emergency services during the Covid-19 pandemic.

item.title: Swansea University shortlisted in Guardian University Awards 2020
item.description: Swansea University has been shortlisted for Best Student Experience in the Guardian University Awards 2020.

item.title: Welsh super database and technology platform play major role in new international Covid-19 research collaboration
item.description: The Secure Anonymised Information Linkage (SAIL) Databank, funded by Health and Care Research Wales, has been selected to play a key role in an international collaboration to accelerate Covid-19 research.

item.title: Helicopter or cartwheel? How molecules rotate determines what happens when they collide with surfaces
item.description: What happens when a molecule collides with a surface? Researchers at Swansea University have shown that the orientation of the molecule as it moves – whether it is spinning like a helicopter blade or rolling like a cartwheel - is important in determining what happens in the collision.

item.title: Couple share happy memories of University dubbed Butlin's-by-the-Sea
item.description: Sandra and Bob Cuthill will definitely be among those raising a glass to Swansea University when it marks its centenary this month.

item.title: £6m EU investment in SPECIFIC Innovation & Knowledge Centre recognises project’s success
item.description: In 2011, SPECIFIC was one of six UK Innovation and Knowledge Centres (IKCs) created by the UK Government.

item.title: Swansea academics join call for statutory levy on gambling firms
item.description: Academics warn current system gives industry too much influence on how money is spent.

item.title: New doctors praised at University’s first-ever virtual graduation celebration
item.description: More than 150 former students reunited to celebrate their time at Swansea University Medical School with a unique virtual graduation celebration.

item.title: Swansea University student receives prestigious Diana Award in recognition of voluntary work
item.description: Isabel Francis, a law student at Swansea University, has been recognised with the highest accolade a young person aged between 9 and 25 can achieve for their social action or humanitarian efforts – The Diana Award.

item.title: Face shields designed by University team get CE mark for safety for NHS to use
item.description: Face shields to protect NHS staff, designed and 3D printed by a Swansea University team, have been awarded the CE safety mark, which means they can now be manufactured at larger scale for hospitals.

item.title: University’s popular bike share scheme re-opens
item.description: Cyclists in Swansea will be back in the saddle from July 1 following the decision to re-open the University’s popular bike share scheme.

item.title: Call to reconnect Europe’s rivers as one million barriers found
item.description: New research has found that Europe’s rivers are the most fragmented in the world, with up to one million barriers blocking their flow, and urgent action to reconnect them is now vital to ensure the long-term health of these rivers and their surrounding habitats.

item.title: Project to help health staff using PPE facemasks communicate scoops innovation award
item.description: Swansea University’s Healthcare Technology Centre has played a key role in developing an award-winning communication aid for frontline health staff forced to wear face masks during the pandemic.

item.title: CSconnected project receives UK government funding through UKRI
item.description: The UK Government has announced the first wave of funding through UK Research and Innovation’s flagship Strength in Places Fund in which a major £43.74M project with South Wales’ compound semiconductor cluster has been approved and will be supported by £25.44M funding from Strength in Places.

item.title: Shaped by Steel - Swansea's first Twitter conference is open to all
item.description: ‘Shaped by Steel’ is the first ever ‘Twitter’ conference to be hosted by Swansea University.  With more traditional ‘face-to-face’ conferences cancelled due to the COVID-19 pandemic, the History Department’s ‘Social Worlds of Steel’ research project team is taking to Twitter as an alternative way to share research and heritage practice to a different audience – the Twittersphere.

item.title: Researchers uncover new environmentally-friendly approach to water treatment
item.description: Researchers from Swansea University have developed a new environmentally friendly method for removing toxic chemicals from water.

item.title: Pioneering single process could help safeguard water quality, environment and health
item.description: A research team at Swansea University have developed a new method for fast removal and detection of wastewater pollutants that come from everyday pharmaceuticals like paracetamol, ibuprofen and aspirin, which could help minimise their impact on the environment.

item.title: Historian’s new book reveals Swansea University’s key role during WW2 and its aftermath
item.description: The history of Swansea University comes under the microscope in a new book published to mark the university’s centenary year in 2020.

item.title: University professor honoured for exceptional contribution to innovation and science
item.description: Swansea University’s Professor Dave Worsley has won a prestigious St David Award for his contribution to Innovation, Science and Technology.

item.title: Young people benefit from Swansea University’s community grant during pandemic
item.description: Swansea University has awarded a community grant of £250 to homelessness charity Llamau.

item.title: Swansea student’s role helping to ensure hospital staff stay protected
item.description: A Swansea University student is playing a key role in managing supplies of PPE at one of the hospitals hit hardest by the pandemic.

item.title: Swansea University researchers take up cancer fundraising baton
item.description: Cancer researchers from Swansea University have set themselves the epic challenge of cycling more than 4,500km this June to raise money for Tenovus Cancer Care and Maggies Cancer Centres.

item.title: Academi Hywel Teifi contributes to Tafwyl’s programme of events
item.description: The partnership between Swansea University's Academi Hywel Teifi and Tafwyl continues once again this year as the popular festival moves online due to the coronavirus pandemic.

item.title: Free English lessons go online to continue during lockdown
item.description: Swansea University’s free English language lessons for beginners are still going strong despite lockdown.

item.title: Be part of new project to shape mental health and wellbeing support in Wales after Covid-19
item.description: Researchers behind a major new study charting how the people of Wales have coped with coronavirus are appealing for volunteers to share their experiences.

item.title: Recovering from coronavirus: new ventilator can save lives and create jobs
item.description: A team of Swansea doctors and engineers has designed a new ventilator that can be built quickly from local parts and – crucially - used even for patients with severe coronavirus. Until now, ventilator designs could either be one or the other, but not both.

item.title: PhD student wins Swansea University 3MT competition final
item.description: A Swansea University PhD student has won the Swansea University Three Minute Thesis (3MT) final.

item.title: Swansea reaches its highest ever position in the Complete University Guide
item.description: Swansea University has been ranked joint 32nd in the 2021 Complete University Guide League Tables – its highest ever position.

item.title: Real living wage accreditation for Swansea University
item.description: Swansea University has been accredited as a real living wage employer by the Living Wage Foundation (LWF).

item.title: Swansea University student crowned UK FameLab champion
item.description: Swansea University student Rebecca Ellis has been declared this year’s UK champion of FameLab - the world’s foremost science communication competition.

item.title: Discovery: More than 50 years of changing lives
item.description: As part of Volunteers’ Week across the UK (1-7 June), we look at the way Discovery continues to help change lives in South Wales and across the globe.

item.title: S4 Science: Online science resources keep kids learning during lockdown
item.description: Outreach scientists and academics from Swansea University have been hard at work in their kitchens and gardens producing online science workshops, lessons, and science club content to give school students the support and resources they need to continue their science learning from home, during lockdown.

item.title: Researchers develop new method to map cholesterol metabolism in brain
item.description: A team of researchers led by Swansea University have developed new technology to monitor cholesterol in brain tissue which could uncover its relation to neurodegenerative disease and pave the way for the development of new treatments.

item.title: Swansea University announces it will be open and ready to teach at the start of the new academic year
item.description: Swansea University has announced its intention to be open and ready to teach online and in person at the beginning of the new academic year in September 2020.

item.title: Medical School head appointed to board of local NHS
item.description: Professor Keith Lloyd, head of Swansea University’s Medical School, has been appointed Independent Member of the Swansea Bay University Health Board (SBUHB).

item.title: Viruses in lobsters: study sheds light on disease and fragile ecosystems
item.description: Levels of virus infection in lobsters seem to be related to habitat and other species, new studies of Caribbean marine protected areas have shown.

item.title: Imperial Subjects: Wales and South Asia – digital discussion a big success
item.description: A digital discussion session on the imperial links between South Asia and Wales brought together more than 150 delegates from all over the globe, attending via Zoom.

item.title: Swansea University’s double success reaching FameLab final
item.description: Nine of the finest new science voices from across the country, including two from Swansea University, will battle to represent the UK in FameLab – the world’s foremost science communication competition.

item.title: Antarctic climate change research with Tasmania gets go-ahead
item.description: Research into the effect of climate change in the Antarctic has been boosted by an award of $20 million (£10 million) from the Australian government for work led by the University of Tasmania in partnership with Swansea University glaciologists.

item.title: New study examines risks facing frontline medical staff during pandemic
item.description: A leading Swansea University clinician is among a group of experts calling for the introduction of a risk assessment for frontline health professionals treating coronavirus patients.

item.title: Public torn over COVID-19 contact tracing apps, study shows
item.description: A study by researchers at Swansea University and Manchester University suggest that people are torn over whether they will use the COVID-19 contact tracing smartphone app, which is planned for release in the UK later this month.

item.title: Medical School appoints two honorary professors in pharmacy
item.description: Swansea University Medical School has appointed two key members of staff as it prepares to launch its new pharmacy course.

item.title: Swansea academics receive Learned Society of Wales medals
item.description: Two academics from Swansea University are among the latest recipients of the Learned Society of Wales’ medals, announced at the Society’s AGM on Wednesday, 20th May.

item.title: Swansea University experts deliver Welsh-medium science activities online as part of virtual Eisteddfod
item.description: Scientists from Swansea University will launch a series of Welsh-medium online activities for children as part of the alternative, redesigned Urdd National Eisteddfod event to be held online from 25-30 May.

item.title: Hillary Clinton praises Swansea University’s response to Covid-19 crisis
item.description: Secretary Hillary Clinton has praised Swansea University staff and students for their “critical response” to the Covid-19 pandemic.

item.title: Bryan Washington wins £30,000 Swansea University Dylan Thomas Prize
item.description: Twenty-seven-year-old American writer Bryan Washington has been named the winner of the £30,000 Swansea University Dylan Thomas Prize for his debut short story collection, LOT.

item.title: Care homes and frontline housing teams now using University-made hand sanitiser
item.description: Frontline housing workers, homelessness support services and the people they look after, many of whom are vulnerable, are the latest groups to be using hand sanitiser made at Swansea University, where a solar tech lab has temporarily switched to producing 5000 litres a week during the COVID-19 outbreak.

item.title: Medical School wins major boost to nanomedicine research
item.description: Swansea University Medical School has secured a prestigious funding boost to accelerate the transition from discovery research to development projects in the field of nanomedicine.

item.title: £5m funding announced for primary and emergency care research in Wales
item.description: The Welsh Government is to invest £4.85m over the next five years on research into primary and emergency care in Wales, which will involve Swansea University.

item.title: Professor to deliver keynote address at unique virtual research summit
item.description: Swansea University’s Professor Steve Conlan will be the keynote speaker at the world’s first virtual summit on cancer and immunology research.

item.title: Innovative online test set to welcome more international students to Swansea University
item.description: International students who want to study in Swansea will now be able to sit a crucial English language test online, ensuring their University applications can continue as normal.

item.title: Nursing graduate’s pride at being part of NHS
item.description: A Swansea University graduate has spoken of her immense pride at being part of the NHS during the Covid-19 pandemic.

item.title: University's help for disabled people and their Shared Lives carers during lockdown
item.description: Disabled young people and adults will be able to benefit from health and wellbeing advice from Swansea University as they cope with life in lockdown.

item.title: Short story launched for young children in South Wales
item.description: Freshwater Interdisciplinary Research and Engagement (FIRE) Lab at Swansea University have helped launch a short-animated film for young children in South Wales and beyond.

item.title: New study to identify highest risk factors for COVID-19
item.description: Scientists from across the UK, including Swansea University, are calling on the public to sign up to a new study which will help identify who is most at risk of contracting COVID-19 and why some people become more ill than others with the disease.

item.title: Academics help give pupils a virtual view of University life
item.description: Swansea University academics are among the world-leading experts sharing their knowledge to help Welsh sixthformers with their studies during lockdown.

item.title: Research into lockdown: do short-term benefits translate into long-term benefits?
item.description: New research from Swansea University suggests that short, intensive lockdowns to flatten the COVID-19 epidemic curve could actually cost more lives – and instead the overall case numbers could be minimized by introducing a range of measures over a long period of time.

item.title: Nursing students say they are ready to play their part during pandemic
item.description: Swansea nursing students say they are proud to be able to face the challenge of joining the NHS during the pandemic.

item.title: The show must go on! Swansea student helps keep choir singing during pandemic
item.description: They may not be able to rehearse in person but a Swansea University student has found a way for his choir to keep performing during the coronavirus outbreak.

item.title: University announces new three-year partnership with Swansea City
item.description: Swansea University is delighted to announce a new three-year partnership with Swansea City Football Club until the end of the 2022-23 season.

item.title: Waves and tides overshadow human impact on marine life in Swansea Bay
item.description: The biggest impacts on the sea life in Swansea Bay come from waves and tides rather than human activity, a wide-ranging new study - encompassing over 170 species of fish and other sea life such as crabs, squid and starfish - has revealed.

item.title: University’s link to Wuhan brings experts together in fight against Covid-19
item.description: Swansea University has used its unique connection to Wuhan to bring together health experts from across Wales with some of the first medics to tackle coronavirus.

item.title: Researchers looking for child participants in online survey on health and wellbeing
item.description: Researchers at Swansea University are looking to ask children age 8-11 to take part in an online questionnaire to understand more about their health and wellbeing during the Covid-19 lockdown.

item.title: Swansea University academics Honoured by Welsh Academy
item.description: Five Swansea University academics are among the new entrants to the Learned Society of Wales’ Fellowship.

item.title: Funding for team to test speed clean of ambulances carrying Covid-19 patients
item.description: Swansea University has successfully won funding to reduce the time it takes to sanitise ambulances after carrying a suspected Covid-19 positive patient.

item.title: University language training beats lockdown by launching online CELTA programme
item.description: Swansea University’s English Language Training Services is continuing to run its prestigious Cambridge CELTA programme despite the lockdown.

item.title: Experts demand urgent government action to prevent coronavirus suicide risk
item.description: Governments need to give ‘urgent consideration’ to their public health response to prevent any   possible impact of the coronavirus pandemic on the number of suicides, experts warn.

item.title: School of Law’s research centre invited to join global counter-terrorism research network
item.description: The Cyber Threats Research Center (CYTREC), based at the Hillary Rodham Clinton School of Law at Swansea University, has been formally invited to join the United Nations Counter-Terrorism Committee Executive Directorate’s (CTED) Global Research Network (GRN).

item.title: Swansea University professor becomes Fellow of the Academy of Social Sciences
item.description: Swansea University academic Norah Keating is among a group of eminent social scientists who have been honoured by the Academy of Social Sciences.

item.title: Extinction of threatened marine megafauna would lead to huge loss in functional diversity
item.description: The extinction of threatened marine megafauna species could result in larger than expected losses in functional diversity, according to research led by Swansea University.

item.title: Coronavirus lockdown: new study into the effect on physical activity and wellbeing
item.description: A team of researchers has launched a new study to examine the effect of the UK Government’s lockdown strategy on the population’s physical activity levels and wellbeing during the Covid-19 pandemic.

item.title: COVID-19 social distancing having significant impact on mental health, study shows
item.description: A study by researchers at Swansea University and Manchester University shows social distancing and isolation is having a significant impact on people’s mental health and emotional wellbeing.

item.title: Trio of Swansea University scientists go from lab bench to backbench
item.description: A trio of Swansea University scientists swapped their lab coats for legislation when they spent a week in Westminster at the Houses of Parliament and Whitehall.

item.title: University psychologists provide support to isolated patients
item.description: Swansea patients whose appointments have had to be cancelled because of coronavirus are getting expert support over the phone instead so they can continue their treatment.

item.title: Swansea students develop solution to improve emergency vehicle response times
item.description: A team of Swansea University students have developed a solution to improve emergency vehicle response times in a worldwide competition involving over 40 universities.

item.title: From solar to sanitiser – Uni team producing 5000 litres a week for NHS
item.description:
A solar tech lab at Swansea University has temporarily switched to producing 5000 litres of hand sanitiser a week, to help the NHS fight the Covid-19 outbreak.   

The sanitiser, which meets the standard set by the World Health Organization, is already in use in the local NHS.

item.title: COVID-19 and the 1918-19 ‘Spanish Flu’: differences give us a measure of hope
item.description: Dr Michael Bresalier, lecturer in the History of Medicine at Swansea University, has published a historical perspective that highlights important differences between COVID-19 and the 1918-19 influenza pandemic.

item.title: Technocamps shortlisted for new Welsh STEM Award
item.description: Swansea University’s innovative schools’ outreach programme is in the running for a top award for its work promoting diversity in the world of science education.

item.title: University maternity expert hosting free online antenatal classes
item.description: Mums-to-be whose antenatal classes have had to be cancelled because of the coronavirus are now taking advantage of free online advice from a Swansea University expert.

item.title: Student support for disabled people continues through virus crisis
item.description: Student volunteers who work with disabled adults are staying in touch with them despite the coronavirus crisis, by offering support over the phone and getting them involved in online activities to help others.

item.title: Debut poets dominate the shortlist for the 15th anniversary of the Swansea University Dylan Thomas Prize
item.description: Celebrating the Prize’s 15th anniversary, the Swansea University Dylan Thomas Prize recalls its namesake thanks to the dominance of young and experimental poets showcased on its shortlist each of whom are in the running for the £30,000 prize.

item.title: Medical students join NHS workforce to battle coronavirus
item.description: Final year medical students from Swansea University are joining NHS staff in the fight against Covid-19.

item.title: University’s high-tech help to share vital health information
item.description: Innovation experts at Swansea University are playing a key role in improving the way hospitals use information about patients.

item.title: Couple return to leave their own mark on campus where they met
item.description: A couple returned to Swansea University to leave their own legacy at the place where they first met more than 60 years ago.

item.title: How your CoronaDiary could help us understand more about living through a pandemic
item.description: Has living with isolation and social distancing inspired you to put pen to paper? If so, you could be part of an unique social research project examining how society lives through coronavirus.

item.title: Legal academic helps endorse guidance for home buyers in health crisis
item.description: A Swansea University academic has been working alongside The Law Society to endorse industry-wide guidance to conveyancing firms advising clients on house moves during the coronavirus crisis.

item.title: South Wales industry consortium established to support the NHS covid 19 response
item.description: Teams from across Swansea University are coming together to support a newly established consortium – SWARM (The South Wales Additive and Rapid Manufacturing Consortium) in its mission to support NHS Wales’ covid-19 response.

item.title: Health and Care Research Wales announce £4.5m investment in SAIL Databank
item.description: The new funding, which will maintain SAIL Databank for at least the next 5 years, comes as part of a £44 million investment package from Welsh Government into health and social care research to improve care and services.

item.title: Students get set to support frontline NHS colleagues during virus crisis
item.description: Midwifery and paramedic students from Swansea University will be lending their support to frontline NHS colleagues in the fight to against the coronavirus pandemic.

item.title: Swansea couple produce hand sanitiser amid Covid-19 pandemic
item.description: A Swansea University lecturer and her husband have transformed their popular business to produce approved hand sanitiser amid the ongoing coronavirus pandemic.

item.title: Snake venom evolved for prey not protection
item.description: It is estimated that every year, over 100,000 human deaths can be attributed to snakebite from the world’s 700 venomous snake species – all inflicted in self-defence when the snakes feel threatened by encroaching humans. However, new research from a joint Bangor/Swansea team concludes that snake venom did not evolve as a defence mechanism.

item.title: CADR secures funding boost to support ageing research in Wales
item.description: Swansea University’s Centre for Ageing and Dementia Research (CADR) has been awarded £2.8m in funding to extend their project for a further five years until 2025.

item.title: Technocamps launch virtual resources to aid schools and pupils
item.description: Swansea University’s Technocamps project have launched a series of free online resources to support pupils, teachers and parents amid the Covid-19 outbreak.

item.title: Staff give medical supplies and space to help NHS tackle coronavirus
item.description: Staff at Swansea University have rallied together to provide essential items to their local hospital to support them during the Covid-19 outbreak.

item.title: Students step in to offer childcare to vital health workers
item.description: A group of Swansea University students have come up with a practical way of helping NHS staff during the coronavirus pandemic.

item.title: Semiconductors can behave like metals and superconductors
item.description: The crystal structure at the surface of semiconductor materials can make them behave like metals and even like superconductors, a joint Swansea/Rostock research team has shown. The discovery potentially opens the door to advances like more energy-efficient electronic devices.

item.title: Centenary appeal to former CELTA students
item.description: As part of Swansea University’s Centenary celebrations, its English Language Training Services has embarked on a global hunt to track down former students.

item.title: Swansea University shortlisted for three prestigious nursing awards
item.description: Two outstanding Swansea University students are in the running for the Most Inspirational Student of the Year award in this year’s Student Nursing Times Awards.

item.title: Swansea University playing key role in dementia research
item.description: Health records from over 80% of the Welsh population have been used to create the UK’s first national-scale health database for dementia research, which is housed at Swansea University.

item.title: 750,000 seeds planted in Wales in UK’s biggest seagrass restoration scheme
item.description: Sky Ocean Rescue, WWF and Swansea University have marked a major milestone in the biggest seagrass restoration project ever undertaken in the UK – planting over 750,000 seagrass seeds in Dale Bay in Pembrokeshire.

item.title: University holds bike ride to celebrate International Women’s Day
item.description: Swansea University staff and students celebrated International Women’s Day with a group cycle ride from the University campuses to the Civic Centre.

item.title: Major doctoral training boost for Swansea University
item.description: Swansea University has been awarded £2.9million for the EPSRC Doctoral Training Partnership 2020-21.

item.title: Researchers detect Lamb shift in antihydrogen
item.description: Swansea University physicists, as leading members of the ALPHA collaboration at CERN, have reported the first measurement of fine structure in Antihydrogen that relates to Willis Lamb’s famous discovery almost 70 years ago.

item.title: How best to integrate renewable energy sources into the electricity grid
item.description: A team from the University's Energy Safety Research Institute will be examining how best to integrate renewable energy sources into the UK power grid, helping to cut carbon emissions, thanks to a new £244,000 research award from the Engineering and Physical Sciences Research Council.

item.title: Oriel Science returns to Waterfront Museum for Super Science Swansea
item.description: Swansea University’s Oriel Science will be returning to the National Waterfront Museum on Sunday, 8 March to host “Super Science Swansea” as part of British Science Week.

item.title: Major award for project engaging young people with the world of books
item.description: DylanED, a Swansea University initiative aimed at introducing children and young people to the world of literature, will receive a major boost from the Rhys Davies Trust over the next three years.

item.title: Swansea University expands free legal advice clinic, following surge in demand
item.description: Since launching in August 2017, the number of clients accessing free legal advice from students at Swansea University’s Law Clinic has more than doubled.

item.title: Swansea student stars in Brain Tumour Awareness campaign
item.description: A Swansea University student, who was inspired to pursue a career in healthcare following the death of his father and grandad to brain tumours, is starring in a campaign to help find a cure for the disease.

item.title: Student ambassadors appointed to promote Welsh language study at Swansea University
item.description: The Coleg Cymraeg Cenedlaethol has recruited four student ambassadors at Swansea University who will work to encourage more prospective students to study part of their degree courses through Welsh.

item.title: Swansea to host Richard Burton Film Festival
item.description: Six films starring Richard Burton will be screened at Swansea’s Cinema & Co as part of a one-off festival celebrating the life of the Hollywood icon from Pontrhydyfen.

item.title: Double success for University drug resistance research
item.description: Swansea University research into the threat posed by antifungal drug resistance has been highlighted in two prestigious international journals.

item.title: Smarter, cleaner, greener steel
item.description: Climate change groups, companies and university researchers from across the UK have been exploring how they can contribute to a smart, green and clean steel industry, at an event organised by the Swansea-led SUSTAIN project.

item.title: Major study shows climate change can cause abrupt impacts on dryland ecosystems
item.description: A Swansea University academic has contributed to a major study published in the journal Science, which shows the increases in aridity in some parts of the world may produce abrupt changes of ecosystems in areas where more than 2 billion people live.

item.title: University’s new course gets set to revive city’s pharmacy training tradition
item.description: Plans for the launch of Swansea University’s new pharmacy degree programme are now well under way but it won’t be the first time future pharmacists have been trained in the city.

item.title: Life science innovation project wins extra €5m investment
item.description: A unique Irish-Welsh partnership involving life science expertise at Swansea University has won €5 million of additional funding.

item.title: First Minister launches research centre to develop future engineers in Wales
item.description: New engineering research institute set to deliver high impact, fundamental and applied research through academia-industry partnerships, marked by launch with First Minister.

item.title: The world’s biggest iceberg is about to enter the open ocean
item.description: Scientists from Swansea University have revealed that A68, the world’s largest iceberg, is about to enter the open ocean for the first time.

item.title: University wins funding for two projects to help public contribute to research
item.description: Swansea University has been awarded funding from the UK government for two projects, which will enable the public to contribute to research and innovation projects that affect their lives.

item.title: Volunteers plant 50 oak trees to mark Swansea University’s centenary
item.description: As part of Swansea University’s 100th birthday celebrations, staff and student volunteers have planted 50 oak trees across the University’s Singleton and Bay campuses.

item.title: Student nurse Laura shows her commitment to patient wellbeing
item.description: A Swansea University student has launched a campaign to collect basic toiletries and resources for hospital patients who are unable to access them themselves.

item.title: New bushfire satellite images give early warning of long term effects
item.description: New data from Swansea University has showed that the bushfires raging in Australia are likely to pollute air quality over a very wide geographical area and could have a long term negative impact on public health.

item.title: Awards celebrate research and innovation at Swansea University
item.description: From the screening of infectious diseases, to early diagnosis of bowel cancer, understanding the environmental impact of wildfires, responding to online terrorist propaganda, developing safety equipment for professional athletes and showcasing Science in the community; the astonishing range of research and innovation carried out at Swansea University was in the spotlight at the Research and Innovation Awards 2020.

item.title: University in Top 100 LGBT Inclusive Employers
item.description: Swansea University has been named in the UK’s top 100 most inclusive employers for LGBT staff for the fifth year in a row.

item.title: Swansea Soapbox Science 2020 appeals for speakers
item.description: Swansea University is appealing for female scientists and engineers to take part in this year’s Soapbox Science by hitting the streets of Swansea to share their passion and inspire the next generation of scientists.

item.title: University joins quest to discover why some patients stay cancer-free
item.description: Eminent philanthropist and three-time cancer survivor James Hull has joined forces with six universities across the country to investigate why cancer returns in some people and not others.

item.title: Swansea University awarded Erasmus funding to support Texas student exchanges
item.description: Swansea University has been awarded €131,400 (£112,588) funding to support student mobility between Swansea and the University of Houston.

item.title: International and under-represented voices dominate the longlist for the 15th anniversary of the Swansea University Dylan Thomas Prize
item.description: This year's Swansea University Dylan Thomas Prize longlist combines a rich, international collection of young, experimental writers who are offering platforms for under-represented voices and exploring pressing social and world themes across identity, culture and power.

item.title: Swansea zoologist wins prestigious Humboldt Research Award
item.description: Rory Wilson, a distinguished professor of zoology at Swansea University, has been granted a Humboldt Research Award by the Alexander von Humboldt Foundation of Germany.

item.title: From touchscreens to 5G: carbon nanotube production gets green light
item.description: A new method of producing carbon nanotubes -  tiny molecules with incredible physical properties used in touchscreen displays (pictured), 5G networks and flexible electronics – has been given the green light by researchers, meaning work in this crucial field can continue.

item.title: Swansea University Dylan Thomas Prize heads to Jaipur Literature Festival to announce its 2020 longlist live in celebration of its 15th year
item.description: To celebrate 15 years of the Swansea University Dylan Thomas Prize, the Prize is announcing this year's longlist live from the Jaipur Literature Festival.

item.title: Cancer diagnosis centre cuts waits from 84 days to 6
item.description: A rapid diagnosis centre has cut waiting times for patients with non-specific symptoms who may have cancer from 84 days to 6, and it costs less than current usual care if used at more than 80% of capacity, a new study by Swansea University researchers and NHS colleagues has shown.

item.title: Multi-million pound funding secured for City Deal
item.description: A multi-million pound early new year present has arrived to turbo-charge the Swansea Bay City Deal.

item.title: University-designed programme increases children’s knowledge of their carbon footprint
item.description: An interdisciplinary team at Swansea and Bangor universities have designed a programme which encourages school-aged children to think about their personal impact on climate change.

item.title: Internet use reduces study skills in university students
item.description: Research conducted at Swansea University and the University of Milan has shown that students who use digital technology excessively are less motivated to engage with their studies, and are more anxious about tests.  This effect was made worse by the increased feelings of loneliness that use of digital technology produced.

item.title: Student entrepreneurs win support from successful alumni in new mentorship programme
item.description: Successful formers students have returned to Swansea University to help encourage the next generation of young entrepreneurs.

item.title: International experts call for unified approach to addressing loneliness in letter to The Lancet
item.description: International experts, including researchers from Swansea University, have published a letter in The Lancet medical journal calling for a unified approach to addressing the global challenge of loneliness.

item.title: University pays tribute to Taliesin pioneer Sybil Crouch
item.description: It is with great sadness that we heard Sybil Crouch, formerly the Head of Cultural Services and leader of Taliesin Arts Centre at Swansea University, has died.

item.title: New research shows domestic animals link virus spread among humans and wildlife
item.description: Our domesticated animals - both pets and livestock – hold the key to the spread of viruses among humans and wildlife according to new research involving Swansea University.

item.title: New breastfeeding textbook to give support to medical professionals
item.description: A new textbook aimed at supporting the medical profession to give accurate and up-to-date breastfeeding guidance is released.

item.title: New study shows how patients’ health values can impact vital pelvic floor treatment
item.description: Researchers and health professionals in Swansea have revealed the value women put on their own health can have a direct effect on the success of medical treatment for pelvic floor problems.

item.title: Swansea University celebrates first degree apprenticeship graduates in Wales
item.description: Swansea University is this week celebrating the success of the first degree apprenticeship graduates in Wales.

item.title: Students plant 800 new trees on city’s Kilvey Hill
item.description: Students have planted nearly 800 new trees on Swansea’s Kilvey Hill,  helped by local residents, scouts and police officers, in a community event funded by the University.

item.title: Research finds positive community action can help coral reef health
item.description: New research has found that positive community action can boost fish numbers in coral reefs and safeguard fish numbers there in the future.

item.title: Student overcomes life-changing health setbacks to secure Master’s
item.description: A Swansea University student who battled back from losing his sight and undergoing a kidney transplant is celebrating after graduating with a master’s degree.

item.title: Swansea University appoints new governing body Chair
item.description: Swansea University is pleased to announce that Bleddyn Phillips has been appointed as its new Chair of Council.

item.title: Five guest judges announced for the 15th anniversary of the Swansea University Dylan Thomas Prize
item.description: To celebrate the 15th anniversary of the Swansea University Dylan Thomas Prize, the custodians of the Prize, Swansea University, have announced for the first time that five guest judges will be joining Chairman Professor Dai Smith CBE and Professor Kurt Heinzelman in selecting the 2020 winner of the world’s biggest prize for young writers.

item.title: Mother overcomes family battle to graduate with law degree
item.description: A Swansea mum whose battle over her autistic son’s education inspired her to study law has now pledged to help other families following her graduation from Swansea University.

item.title: New study reveals steps to suicide prevention in young Welsh people
item.description: Reducing adverse childhood experiences, preventing alcohol and substance misuse, and improving education and training opportunities are some key ways to help prevent suicide in Welsh children and young people.

item.title: Nursing graduate’s new life after winning drugs battle
item.description: A former drug addict who turned her life around has graduated from Swansea University and become a nurse so she can help others.

item.title: Why University is so special to couple after more than 60 years
item.description: A couple who fell in love at Swansea University in the early 1950s say the organisation will always hold a special place in their hearts.

item.title: Outdoor learning is good for pupils and teachers
item.description: Outdoor learning has had a positive impact on both children and staff at a Swansea primary school, boosting their wellbeing and pupil attitudes to learning.

item.title: Swansea become first university in Wales to open zero waste shop
item.description: Swansea University have become the first university in Wales to open a zero waste shop.

item.title: The Welsh Varsity will return to Swansea next year with the university sporting showpiece taking place on Wednesday, April 29.
item.description: The Welsh Varsity will return to Swansea next year with the university sporting showpiece taking place on Wednesday, April 29.

item.title: Art exhibition shares stories from rural Bangladesh
item.description: An exhibition of work by prominent Bangladeshi artists, which draws on the experience of rural poverty in the country, is to open at Swansea University on 19 December.

item.title: Swansea University collaborates with council for woodland project
item.description: Swansea University has helped to restore ancient coppice at Landore Social Club and lay hedges at the Liberty Stadium in a bid to revitalise the Hafod-Morfa Copperworks site with Swansea Council.

item.title: Irish Consul General’s praise for life sciences partnership
item.description: The Irish Consul General to Wales visited Swansea University Medical School for a special briefing about the Celtic Advanced Life Science Innovation Network (CALIN).

item.title: Study shows lake methane emissions should prompt rethink on climate change
item.description: A new study from Swansea University has given new insights into how the greenhouse gas methane is being produced in the surface waters of lakes, which should signal a rethink on the global methane cycle.

item.title: New book discusses why breastfeeding grief and trauma matter
item.description: A new book by a Swansea University academic explores what breastfeeding means to women, how they feel when things don’t work out and importantly, how care, support and outcomes can be improved for future generations of women.

item.title: In profile: Swansea University at CERN
item.description: CERN, the European Organization for Nuclear Research, is one of the world's largest and most respected centres for scientific research. Home to the Large Hadron Collider (LHC), which is located 100m underground and consists of a 27-kilometre ring of superconducting magnets, CERN’s history dates back to the 1940s and is the birthplace of the World Wide Web.

item.title: Twins’ journey to become doctors sees them reunited in Swansea
item.description: Identical twins Will and Alex Carroll-Adams have been reunited at Swansea University as they both pursue their ambition to become doctors.

item.title: University and Swansea Tree Forum plant trees for National Tree Week
item.description: Swansea University’s Energy Safety Research Institute (ESRI) and Swansea Tree Forum have planted a number of trees outside the city’s Guildhall as part of their commitment to offset work related staff travel with tree planting.

item.title: Swansea University collaboration promotes science education in Wales
item.description: Swansea University is collaborating with OXIS Energy UK Ltd to support the development of enhanced lithium metal anodes to improve the cycle life of lithium-sulfur or Li-S batteries, rechargeable batteries, notable for their high specific energy.

item.title: Research shows old newspapers can be used to grow carbon nanotubes
item.description: A research collaboration between Rice University and the Energy Safety Research Institute (ESRI) at Swansea University has found that old newspapers can be used as a low cost, eco-friendly material on which to grow single walled carbon nanotubes on a large scale.

item.title: Academics call for targeted healthcare for pregnant women and new mums with depression
item.description: Swansea University academics are calling for improved and targeted healthcare for pregnant women and new mothers who experience depression, following a new study looking at the impact of depression and anti-depressants.

item.title: Clinton’s call for society to show courage in the face of inequality
item.description: Hillary Rodham Clinton has paid tribute to the women who have inspired her throughout her career at a special event hosted by Swansea University.

item.title: Hillary Clinton meets the first cohort of the Hillary Rodham Clinton Scholarship programme at Swansea University
item.description: Hillary Rodham Clinton led a seminar with the first recipients of the Hillary Rodham Clinton Global Challenges Scholarship at Swansea University’s Singleton Campus earlier today (Thursday 14 November).

item.title: New advanced therapy for endometrial cancer granted US patent
item.description: Swansea University scientists’ hard work in the fight against endometrial cancer has seen them being granted a US patent for pioneering new therapy.

item.title: Technocamps offers curriculum fundamentals to educators across Wales
item.description: Technocamps recently hosted a day of learning for education professionals throughout Wales aimed at inspiring those who work in the sector.

item.title: Universities and the Extinction Rebellion generation
item.description: Today’s students are the Extinction Rebellion generation, global citizens who are more interested in contributing than consuming, Swansea University Vice Chancellor Professor Paul Boyle has told an international audience in Malaysia.

item.title: Swansea University secures £2.5m EU funding for creative ageing project
item.description: Swansea University has secured £2.5m of EU funding to create a new research hub aimed at growing the global market for age-related products and services.

item.title: Academic’s new book helps parents-to-be how spot fake news about pregnancy, birth and babies.
item.description: Swansea academic, bestselling author and leading infant feeding researcher Professor Amy Brown helps parents-to-be how to spot fake news on pregnancy, birth and babies in her new book Informed is Best.

item.title: Crab disease poses threat to shellfish stocks
item.description: Shore crabs carry parasites that pose a major threat to shellfish stocks. In a new study, Swansea University researchers have used several different detection methods, including taking DNA from seawater, to build up the first comprehensive picture of the problem.

item.title: University project helping primary pupils put climate crisis on the agenda
item.description: Primary school children from across Wales united to find out more about the climate crisis and what is being done to combat it.

item.title: Researcher joins Medical School team after gaining European Fellowship
item.description: Swansea University Medical School has welcomed a new researcher under a prestigious European scheme.

item.title: Swansea and Zambia team up to tackle plastic waste
item.description: Teachers and pupils at 14 schools in Swansea and Zambia have teamed up to tackle plastic waste, thanks to a partnership set up by Discovery, the Swansea University student volunteering charity.

item.title: £800,000 award to share benefits of solar technology
item.description: A Swansea-led project which will help communities in developing countries to generate their own solar power has been awarded £800,000 by the UK government.

item.title: £5.6 million investment in legal innovation for Swansea University Law School
item.description: Swansea University and the Welsh Government have today (30 October 2019) announced a £5.6 million investment in LegalTech and Access to Justice, as well as in countering terrorist and criminal use of the internet.

item.title: Dr Bridget Kerr collects award from the Confederation of European Probation
item.description: Swansea University’s Dr Bridget Kerr has won the 2019 Research Award of the Confederation of European Probation (CEP) for her PhD research on evaluation systems for probation services.

item.title: New study reveals girls more likely to be admitted to hospital after self-harming
item.description: Girls in Wales are much more likely to end up in hospital after self-harming than boys according to new research led by Swansea University.

item.title: Professor addresses international conference on academic integrity
item.description: A Swansea University academic has shared his expertise and experience in ethics and academic integrity with an international audience at an EU conference.

item.title: Swansea University joins consortium to develop the next generation of biosciences research and industry leaders
item.description: Swansea University is to join the SWBio Doctoral Training Partnership as an associate partner, following an £18.5m funding from the Biotechnology and Biological Sciences Research Council (BBSRC).

item.title: Bloodhound LSR revealed in ‘desert spec’ ahead of high-speed trials
item.description: The Bloodhound Land Speed Record (LSR) team has revealed the car aiming to claim a new world land speed record next year, seen for the first time in completed desert spec as it begins its high-speed testing programme in the Hakskeenpan desert, Northern Cape, South Africa.

item.title: New study reveals that crabs can solve and remember their way around a maze
item.description: A new Swansea University study has revealed how common shore crabs can navigate their way around a complex maze and can even remember the route in order to find food.

item.title: University highlights global issues at first bioethics conference
item.description: Academics, students and health professionals gathered tackle some of today’s most pressing ethical issues at a special conference at Swansea University.

item.title: Primary pupils share research with leading AMs
item.description: Pupils from two Welsh primary schools have shared concerns about plastic waste and healthy eating with AMs at a special event hosted by Swansea University’s Morgan Academy.

item.title: Wales’ largest science festival returns to Swansea
item.description: Swansea University will once again showcase its inspiring research to the people of Swansea later this month as the Swansea Science Festival returns for a third year.

item.title: Award-winning playwright and artist announced as inaugural Creativity Fellows
item.description: Two artists have been chosen for inaugural Creativity Fellowships, Swansea University’s Cultural Institute has announced.

item.title: University gives pupils first-hand experience of nanotechnology
item.description: Pupils have been given an unique opportunity to find out more about nanotechnology at a special Swansea University workshop aimed at inspiring scientists of the future.

item.title: University honoured for dedication to equality
item.description: Swansea University is celebrating after being rewarded for its ongoing commitment to gender equality.

item.title: University to host charity beach walk
item.description: Swansea University's wellbeing service will be hosting a three-mile charity beach walk to raise awareness of suicide in young people.

item.title: University rewarded with Meningitis Aware Recognition Mark
item.description: Swansea University has retained its Meningitis Aware Recognition Mark for its ongoing commitment to raising awareness of the potentially deadly infection among students and staff.

item.title: Discovering the Mary Rose: Aaarrtt on the High Seas
item.description: A free family fun day all about Henry VIII’s warship the Mary Rose is to headline this year’s Being Human Festival, and visitors are welcomed to climb aboard for fantastical adventures on the high seas.

item.title: New £4.6m hub boosts access to vital data that will help transform respiratory health in the UK
item.description: Swansea University’s SAIL Databank plays key role in a £4.6m UK-wide consortium on improving lives of millions with respiratory illness.

item.title: New Ireland and Wales marine energy project launched at Ocean Energy Europe Conference
item.description: A new €4.2m cross-border project aiming to boost the marine energy industry in Wales and Ireland has been launched by Lesley Griffiths AM, the Welsh Minister for Environment, Energy and Rural Affairs.

item.title: £10m funding boost for adolescent mental health research
item.description: A pioneering research centre focused on understanding and developing new ways of reducing anxiety and depression in young people will be established with funding of £10m from a major UK charity, the Wolfson Foundation.

item.title: High-tech opportunities set to inspire pupils
item.description: The holidays may be over but thanks to Technocamps, school pupils will be taking new skills and experiences into their next term.

item.title: Rare Japanese knotweed hybrid found in south Wales
item.description: A team of Swansea University scientists have discovered a rare Japanese knotweed hybrid in south Wales.

item.title: Acclaimed author Max Porter to discuss new novel at University event
item.description: Max Porter, the winner of the 2016 Swansea University Dylan Thomas Prize for his internationally-acclaimed debut novel 'Grief is the Thing with Feathers' , will join Dr Francesca Rhydderch at Swansea University to discuss and read from his globally anticipated, Booker longlisted second novel, Lanny.

item.title: University teams up with pharmacy chain ahead of new course
item.description: Students on Swansea University’s upcoming pharmacy course will be able to see high-tech developments in community pharmacy care at first hand, thanks to a new partnership.

item.title: Kindness is a top priority in a long-term partner according to a new international study
item.description: One of the top qualities that we look for in a long-term partner is kindness, according to new research by Swansea University.

item.title: Swansea University remains top in Wales in The Times and Sunday Times Good University Guide 2020
item.description: Swansea University has retained its position as the highest ranked university in Wales in The Times and Sunday Times Good University Guide 2020.

item.title: Future Leaders: volcano expert and mathematician win fellowships to conduct research at Swansea
item.description: Two researchers, a mathematician and a volcano expert, have been awarded Future Leaders fellowships by the UK government which will see them come to Swansea University to take forward their research.

item.title: Brexit referendum study finds voter fragmentation led to leave win
item.description: A new inter-disciplinary study by Swansea University mathematics and economics academics of the 2016 Brexit referendum, has shown that support for the Leave campaign drew from a far more similar demographic than the Remain campaign, which may have had implications in mobilising votes for those campaigning to stay in the EU.

item.title: A greener car industry - award for researcher’s work to cut energy used in car manufacturing
item.description: A Swansea University researcher who is developing more environmentally friendly techniques for car manufacturing has won a £1000 award from the Worshipful Livery Company of Wales, which will allow him to share his work with fellow experts.

item.title: University joins forces with college to help autistic students
item.description: Swansea University and Gower College Swansea have teamed up to support students with autistic spectrum conditions as they prepare to make the transition from college to university.

item.title: The life aquatic made clear with freshwater lens
item.description: A Swansea University doctoral student has found a way to view the life of plants and animals in murky waters – by using a lens of freshwater.

item.title: University celebrates the success of the first Degree Apprenticeship Graduates in Wales
item.description: Students and staff from Swansea University’s Degree Apprenticeship Programme in Applied Software Engineering recently gathered with local businesses and organisations to celebrate the success of the first learners to complete the three year course.

item.title: University partnership provides unique training environment for health students
item.description: Health students at Swansea University are now able to learn vital skills at a unique new training facility in the heart of a busy hospital.

item.title: University to host Symposium on City Deals
item.description: Are city deals the way ahead for those regions starved of private sector investment? That is the question being posed at a Swansea University conference for academics, politicians and those people most affected by the four regional partnerships being developed across Wales.

item.title: Academics call for structured drug monitoring in care homes
item.description: Swansea University academics call for policy makers, regulators and healthcare professionals to adopt a structured medicine monitoring system after research showed a positive impact on the care of people living in care homes and taking mental health medicines.

item.title: One million seeds to be planted in UK’s biggest seagrass restoration scheme
item.description: Sky Ocean Rescue, leading conservation organisation WWF and Swansea University are launching the biggest seagrass restoration project ever undertaken in the UK, to help this important habitat to thrive once again.

item.title: New study reveals carbon nanotubes measurement possible for the first time
item.description: Swansea University scientists have reported a new approach to measuring the conductivity between identical carbon nanotubes which could be used to help improve the efficiency of electrical power cables in the future.

item.title: University celebrates forging closer bonds with Texan partners
item.description: Swansea University has strengthened its long-standing links with Texas during a high-profile visit to the state by Vice-Chancellor Paul Boyle.

item.title: Professor wins international award for ongoing global collaborations
item.description: A leading Swansea University scientist has been named as the first winner of a prestigious international honour.

item.title: WISERD to receive major funding from ESRC to continue civil society research
item.description: A pioneering research collaboration involving Swansea University has won a multi-million pound funding boost.

item.title: Students use competition to accelerate their business journey
item.description: Entrepreneurial student from Swansea University are celebrating after winning cash backing to help them develop their unique business ideas.

item.title: Medical School appoints new Head of Graduate Entry Medicine
item.description: Swansea University Medical School has appointed a new Head of Graduate Entry Medicine.

item.title: Safer roads – research could lead to better witness evidence from road traffic collisions
item.description: Getting better witness evidence in road traffic collisions, which is essential in prosecuting dangerous drivers, is the aim of a research trial currently being carried out by Swansea University experts and South Wales Police.

item.title: Graduates team up to make their green dream a reality
item.description: A trio of Swansea students didn’t just bond over their passion for the planet, they went on to a forge fantastic new idea for a green business of their own.

item.title: Law professor’s dedication rewarded with national honour
item.description: A Swansea University academic has been recognised for his dedication to teaching and inspiring the next generation of lawyers.

item.title: School pupils experience Swansea University for activity day
item.description: Hosted by the University’s Welfare@CampusLife team, Year 10 pupils at Bishop Gore Comprehensive School in Sketty got the chance to try the Skills for Life programme offered to students.

item.title: £1.3m funding boost for south Wales’ semiconductor industry
item.description: The Welsh Government has announced a new £1.3 million project to develop world-leading process technologies for a range of applications, including autonomous vehicles, novel devices for clean energy, future mobility, artificial intelligence, advanced packaging, and biosensors and wearable sensors.

item.title: Study shows Britain can expect warmer summers to be wetter
item.description: A study of twelve centuries of climate reveal Europe should prepare for wetter as well as drier summers as the climate warms.

item.title: Inaugural Biopesticide Summit provides platform for international collaboration
item.description: Swansea University and Swansea University-based company Bionema Ltd hosted the inaugural Biopesticide Summit in July this year, with the aim of providing an international platform for collaboration and partnership.

item.title: Diabetes experts share innovative research into elite cycling team
item.description: Sport and exercise science experts from Swansea University have shared their world-leading research into how elite cyclists contend with diabetes at an international conference.

item.title: New scholarship to mark Hywel Teifi Edwards’ significant contribution to Welsh culture
item.description: Swansea University’s Academi Hywel Teifi has launched an appeal to establish a new scholarship in memory of Hywel Teifi Edwards at the Eisteddfod in Llanrwst.

item.title: Brewing up a storm! Orders pour in for former student's alcohol-free beer
item.description: A former Swansea University student has shaken up the drinks industry with her non-alcoholic craft beer business.

item.title: Students launch discount app to help revitalise the high street
item.description: Two Swansea University students have launched an app that will allow people to gain exclusive discounts around Swansea and in turn help local charities and independent businesses.

item.title: Swansea University celebrate highest-ever BUCS finish
item.description: With a new academic year around the corner, Swansea University and its sports teams celebrated their highest-ever finish in a British Universities & Colleges Sport (BUCS) season.

item.title: Students launch retro and vintage clothing store in city centre
item.description: two swansea university students have tapped into the growing demand for retro and second-hand clothing with the opening of their vintage clothes store in swansea.

item.title: New study shows charred vegetation remains help to lessen overall carbon emission from wildfires
item.description: The extensive outbreak of wildfires in the arctic and the vast amounts of CO2 they are emitting have been hitting the headlines across the world with their extent being unprecedented since satellite observations of fire began.

item.title: The True Value of Higher Education
item.description: The past few weeks have seen thousands of students in Wales receive long-awaited exam results, following a return to pre-Covid assessment measures.

item.title: The Future of International Higher Education and Internationalisation
item.description: In this article Professor Judith Lamie PhD, Pro Vice-Chancellor for International, shares her thoughts on the changing international higher education landscape.

item.title: Meeting Global Challenges
item.description: After what was another challenging year Professor Paul Boyle, Vice-Chancellor for Swansea University, explores how the experience of 2021 has highlighted the significant, and often lifesaving, impact of research.

item.title: A second century of making waves
item.description: After what has been a very challenging year for communities across the globe Professor Helen Griffiths, Pro-Vice-Chancellor for Research and Innovation, discusses how, through it's research expertise, Swansea University is bringing together people and ideas to help shape our world for the better.

item.title: The Morgan Advanced Studies Institute: Discovery and Innovation to Change the World
item.description: The Morgan Advanced Studies Institute (MASI) launched on 26 February 2021 as Wales’ first Advanced Studies Institute focussed on transformative interdisciplinary research. Here Professor Matt Jones, Founding Director of Morgan Advanced Studies Institute, talks about what MASI is and what it means for Swansea, the wider region, Wales and the world.

item.title: A foundation for excellence Swansea University’s learning and teaching research
item.description: Swansea University's School of Education was opened a couple of years ago and is already gaining a national and international reputation for its work on education and learning across the lifecycle and throughout a range of educational institutions. Here, Professor Martin Stringer, Pro-Vice-Chancellor for Education, takes a look at the research that is taking place across Swansea University into learning and teaching.
